characters: FIRE SWEEPS AWAY THE CLUTTER OF THE
REMAIN CALM. THIS IS A ROUTINE FIRE
RETURN TO YOUR HOMES. CURFEW IS IN
ALARM. REMAIN CALM OR RIOT TROOPS
THEY'RE GONNA COME AND BURN US,
OR IS IT BECAUSE YOUR NAME'S

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: IN SLO-MO, an object falls through frame -- a book. Rolli tumbling. Dropping from sight. Soon: Another book. And another. Books. Falling. And soon: Raining. It's raining books. Why? Now comes a VOICE, softly, sharing his most quiet and pre thoughts:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I love the soot. I love the heat. I love the moment of combustion. Most of all, the smell of kerosene. Here is what I know: "Fire is bright. Fire is clean. It is good to burn." (beat) It is all I need to know. CuT TO: A KLAXON HORN BLARING. RED LIGHTS SPINNING. A fire alarm

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -- summoning to action: FIREMEN, running, boots all a-scuffle, grabbing HELMETS o pegs, yanking EQUIPMENT from storage lockers, cascading d rows of brass poles through holes in the floor... They swarm their beloved FIRE TRUCK, the Salamander, ever climbing up and taking positions on the running platforms dropping external seats and strapping in... The ENGINES START, a turbine WHINE exploding to a DEEP BA ROAR. Like a dragon waking up. Ready to breathe flame. Headlights blaze to life. EMERGENCY STROBES turn the worl surreal. The Salamander moves out, the dragon leaving its cave on massive multi-axle wheels...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..and emerging into the night. Following close behind the Salamander is a second vehicle the CONTROL VAN -- armored, black, unfathomable. HOMELESS. PEOPLE scatter from their path. Traffic pulls o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noise and fury. CAPTAIN BEATTY looks back from his seat, enjoying the expressions on the faces of his men -- tense exhilarated. He sees GUY MONTAG grinning into the wind.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Good for you, Montag!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That grin! The fierce grin of all men singed and driven back by flame!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I love it, sir! Beatty turns forward again, smiling...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I know you do, son.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Form up! Eyes front! curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and SCORES OF POLISHED BOOTS CLAP LIKE THUNDER. SCORES POLISHED HELMETS, gleaming black and bearing the mark of snap in one direction. SCORES OF FIREMEN, chiseled of sto true believers all, stand ready. Stepping before them, boots treading the silence with hol authority, is Beatty. A man of power. Of conviction. A ma who knows his place in the world. He stops. Takes them all in, his men of faith. He loves t more than he loves himself. In a voice that fills the hal

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: An emperor of ancient China said: "History begins with me." (pause) He was wrong. History begins with us.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The Salamander rises hugely into view, cresting a street. NEIGHBORS are pouring from their homes to watch. SEARCHLI

probe from the sky as POLICE HOVERCOPTERS circle whisper- overhead. The Salamander stops with a HISS OF BRAKES. The control v past it, taking up a supporting position. POLICE VEHICLES arriving to provide backup. Firemen swarm from the Salamander, the night chaotic with LIGHTS and running men. Beatty leads Montag and the others up a squalid lawn towa house. A MAN'S face, white and terrified, watches them ap through the cracked panes of a window.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (shouting, muffled) Go away! You've got the wrong house!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, CONTROL PERSONNEL are studying the action on b of MONITORS, recording everything. One monitor flashes an incoming message: "Warrant Authorization."

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER VOICE
dialogues.text: Warrant is good. You have Supreme Court approval to proceed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Beatty and his men arrive at the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Go away, I said! There's nothing here!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Indeed. (turns to his men) There never is. They rush the door with RAMS, blowing through it like a f They swarm in, trailed by Beatty --

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let me hear it, you men!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -- and their voices boom like cannons:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: And why is it good to burn? What does fire do?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: And why is that good, you men? What does that provide?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Let me hear it!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Again!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A HANDHELD SCENE of screaming chaos:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I told you there's nothing here! The WIFE launches herself at the husband, slapping him, flailing and screaming --

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Idiot! I told you this would happen! I told you!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up! -- and the firemen separate them, restraining them both, eyes landing on Beatty as:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: He's right...there’s nothing here...nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatty raises his PLASMA SCREEN CLIPBOARD, studies it:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ~ Mr. and Mrs....Mugniani? Did I pronounce that right? His eyes go to THREE SHRIEKING CHILDREN being herded into room by the firemen.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: And the three Mugniani children. Victor, Paul...and little Emily...

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: -..-no...don't hurt them...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Madam, please. We're not savages, after all. (to his men) Outside. The family is dragged out, the woman SCREAMING as she's p out the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag? If you please?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Sir! (turns to the men)

dialogues.speaker: LET'S GO
dialogues.text: -+-and they spread throughout the house, tossing the plac pounding on walls and listening for the hollow sounds...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -.-While the images are fed to the monitor screens in rea time from the firemen's helmet-cams, recording everything

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Beatty waits in the whirlwind, serene, taking it all in.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: comes to a floor-to-ceiling display shelf lined with dish and bric-a-brac. He runs his hand up the side, trying to his fingers behind it. It's sealed to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Shelf!
He pulls an X-RAY WAND as two firemen rush to his side, a pulling wands. Montag activates his, playing a lavender l He taps a button on his helmet, causing a clear RED VISOR lower over his eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which, in combination with the wand, gives an X-RAY IM through the shelves and into the wall. He sweeps the wand seeing vague shapes appearing like ghosts -- tall, slende rectangular, hidden in the wall among the studs.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I got something.

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: Me too!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (clicks his comlink) Control?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: We're seeing the ghost images in the wall coming across t monitors. CONTROLLER #1 taps his keyboard...

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Hold on. Hold on. -+-and a computer schematic forms on screen, outlining th shapes in glowing red lines. The computer extrapolates th image, lifting one of the objects out as an animated wire form. It's a book. The computer revolves the image, openi the covers, riffling the pages.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: You're confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag and the others jam pry bars behind the shelf, ripp it loose from the wall in an explosion of plaster and woo It topples, revealing a hidden library, the space in the lined with books. They start pulling out armloads of books, hurling them ac the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the search continues. Firemen play wands on sofas...ov floors...up walls...across the ceiling. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: Attic! I got a crawl space!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (glances up) Attic. How original.

dialogues.speaker: TIMECUT
dialogues.text: A PAIR OF ROARING CHAINSAWS rise up on long extensions an chew into the ceiling, spewing debris, cutting two long parallel grooves down the hallway... ...and the ceiling collapses, dropping awesomely into the hallway bringing a ton of books with it. The dust doesn't even have time to clear before another s of the ceiling unexpectedly gives way -- -- and a YOUNG MAN plummets as well. He hits the floor ha scrambles to his feet in the billowing plaster dust, wild with fear and adrenaline, swinging a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: BASTAAARDS
dialogues.text: Montag gets hit in the arm and spins against the wall, clutching his bicep. The kid keeps swinging, scattering f as he flees down the hall and out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: (amped up) Go after him?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: No, let the Hound deal with it. (raises his plasma screen) ) Montag? Injured?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No! I'm okay! (to the others) Let's keep going!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That's the spirit... (tapping his touch screen) ---hmmm. Our unexpected guest would be who? The nephew? Beatty's clipboard brings up an image of the young man's

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, here it is. Nephew. Joseph. (as data scrolls) Physiologicals...DNA...
Beatty inputs the data and enters a command: "Activate Ho He hits the send button with a flourish.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (passing by) What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (smiles) It means: "Good boy. Fetch."

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The "kennel" at the rear of the truck opens, steel plates fanning out to reveal darkness within. We hear something stir...something metallic. A pair of ey activate, glowing red. It emerges into half-light with a SOFT WHINE of servos an gears -- the head of a dog rendered in alloy and chromium steel. We hear a GROWL rising in its manufactured throat. It leaps out, revealed fully as it hits the pavement on r padded paws. The MECHANICAL HOUND. A living Deco sculptur chromium canine nightmare. The neighbors shout, thrilling at the sight of it, some c and whistling, others drawing back in giddy carnival fear The Hound takes off running like a heat-seeking missile.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Joseph, the nephew, is running, still clutching the bat. suddenly stops, hearing: A DISTANT HOWL. The Hound. It's for him. The young man keeps going, gasping in panic..

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -while Beatty assesses the shambles of the house, kicking through snowdrifts of books at his feet. He picks one up, idly flips a page or two.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Beacon on the lawn?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Yes, why not? Give the neighbors a thrill. Good for public relations. Montag grins, waving the others toward the door...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Scooper! Let's give 'em a show!

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...and Joseph runs, twisting and turning down the alleywa looking over his shoulder as if the devil were in pursuit

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A SCOOPER, a mini electric bulldozer, dumps a final load books atop a "beacon" -- a round titanium-mesh platform t looks like a trampoline. Plenty of updraft. As the Scooper backs away, we ANGLE TO:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Pumpers! And double-timing into the shot are a DOZEN FIREMEN with kerosene pumpers on their backs, led by:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Dillman! You're on beacon! Rest of you, with me! They run toward the house, snapping gas masks across thei faces. Dillman veers off toward the beacon...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -.-While Montag and the rest enter, spreading out. They b pumping kerosene throughout the house, soaking the walls, heaps of books, the furniture, priming it like a bomb...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ++-and still Joseph runs...breath exploding...feet poundi the asphalt...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -.-and the firemen back up to the truck to hang the pumpe on their frames. They unbuckle the straps, shrug free. Six men (including Montag) turn as the other firemen help them into their special padding, their long coats of fire retardant leather, their thick gloves, their blast helmet

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -.-and Joseph glances back, his worst nightmare realized the Hound appears from the darkness, veering in pursuit..

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and we see Joseph through the eyes of the Hound, broad live over monitors in ghastly tones of night-vision green

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: We have target acquisition.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...feet pound...rubber-padded paws pursue...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-.and the six firemen back up to the truck again, shrug now into the straps of the FLAMETHROWERS lining the vehic Buckles are snapped. They lift the flamethrowers onto the backs -- twin tanks, ribbed copper hose, nozzles of chrom

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...and the Hound makes a flying leap, taking Joseph to th pavement in a snarl of glittering titanium teeth...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and Joseph's screaming face comes over the monitor scr as the Hound savages him, chomping viciously down on his

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...and the Hound's HYPODERMIC TONGUE whines from its thro plunging.the needle deep into Joseph's flesh, the amber contents emptying as the plunger depresses. Soon Joseph s screaming and goes dopey from the drug...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: .-while Beatty receives the information on his plasma scr clipboard: "Suspect In Custody."

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Procaine. That should calm him down. He turns, motioning "proceed."

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG AND THE FIREMEN
dialogues.text: approach six abreast, fully clad in protective gear, helm gleaming, flamethrower nozzles held like weapons.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Fire is bright. Fire is clean...
They stop in a row, activating their gas feeds with a SOF HISS. Others rush in with igniters, providing the spark. flames are lit, billowing up from the nozzles like torche

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ...fire sweeps away the clutter of the past. It is harmony...serenity... and light. It is our credo...our religion...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ...and we are its high priests. We say mass at flashpoint. Deliver our benediction at four hundred and fifty one degrees of Fahrenheit. We soothe the world with our nozzles of chromium steel, absolve its sins with our sermons of heat. And when the sermon is done, we've turned sorrow and lies to ash, like alchemists and magicians of old. (beat) Let me hear it again, you men! Inspire me! Their voices boom again like cannons:

dialogues.speaker: IS GOOD TO BURN
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLES INTO the arrow-straight lines of firemen to settle upon Montag. Proud. Shouting loudest of all...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: .--and Montag steps onto the lawn, the other firemen fall into flanking positions at his side. They set their feet, their flamethrowers at the beacon -- --and begin to burn. WHOOOOOSH--BOOM! STREAMS OF FIRE sho across the lawn and the beacon erupts skyward on a BALL O FLAME. Everybody shies back, the bonfire lighting up the pushing everybody back with heat. Captain Beatty sees the husband and wife in custody. His attention goes to the children, staring at the flames wit tear-streaked faces. He crouches, gentle:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Here's a good lesson for you children. You'll remember this. (brushes the little girl's cheek) Be good citizens.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIREMEN
dialogues.text: turn to the house. Montag takes lead position, fires a flamethrower blast through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: There's an awesome beat as the kerosene fumes ignite, the very air itself catching fire...followed by a stunning SE OF BOOMING DETONATIONS hurtling down hallways and through rooms, funnels of flame ROARING like living things, shatt glass and peeling walls, eating piles of books.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The living room EXPLODES, blowing the windows out into th street, staggering Montag back on a concussion wave of he The other firemen join in, hosing the house with flame fr all directions. EXPLOSIONS punch through the roof, blow o the walls, hurl enormous BALLS OF FLAME into the night sk

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: backs away with the others, seared by the heat. CAMERA CLOSES IN on him as he snaps his protective facepl up and wrenches his breather mask aside, wanting to feel heat on his goddamn face. Exhilarated. Worshipping the fl And as we COME INTO CLOSE-UP, we again hear his voice spe his most quiet and precious thoughts:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Four hundred and fifty one degrees of Fahrenheit. This is where I live. The rest is just waiting...and kerosene dreams. The flames billow into the sky, roiling smoke as we

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It's dark. Quiet. Montag's freshly showered and wearing h off duty uniform. He pulls his fireman's ID necklace from peg on the locker door, kisses the good luck pendant, han the simple chain around his neck. The fireman's credo ("F
is bright, fire is clean...") is taped inside the locker, alongside a photo of his wife MILLIE. He shuts the locker, grabs his gym bag...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and moves through the firehouse. The late shift is set in, some men on bunks, others engaged in quiet activity. passes a poker game in progress. A few men mutter "good-n Montag pauses at the Captain's door, sees Beatty working his desk in a pool of light. Beatty senses him, glances u

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Heading home?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Soon as I finish my report. You're mentioned. Damn fine work earlier, my boy. Well done.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Good night. Sleep the sleep of the just. Montag moves on. As he approaches the brass poles, he pas The Mechanical Hound. Lying in its firehouse kennel with head on its paws. Waiting. Patient as only a machine can Montag grabs a brass pole and plummets from view as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag walks with his gym bag. HOMELESS PEOPLE are cluste around trash can fires, milling like herd animals. Those see him coming make sure to get out of his way. Firemen a clearly figures of authority to be feared and respected. PLASMA VIDEO DISPLAYS are everywhere -- monitor screens o street corners, huge projections on the sides of building ads playing on the sides of buses like living billboards. have seen the future, and it ain't quiet -- everywhere yo look, they're trying to sell you or convince you. Montag heads up the steps to:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Several large public VIDEO DISPLAYS are playing the lates war news, showing a hallucinatory montage of night-vision smart bomb explosions set to stirring theme music. Montag stares at the images as he stands waiting for his train.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ..-while hours ago a stunning precision strike leveled half the enemy capital in retaliation for the cowardly attack last Wednesday that claimed the lives of 241 of our brave coalition Marines... . A MAG-LEV TRAIN arrives, gliding silently in. He gets o

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Even here the media barrage continues -- what years ago w have been silent advertising placards lining the car on b sides are, in this day and age, moving video and sound im Buy this. Buy that. Hey, have you heard the latest? Be su to tune in! The hottest infotainment! The best gossip! Montag sits with the glazed expression of a veteran commu pretty much tuning it out. Some of his fellow PASSENGERS nervous looks his way, but Montag ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS AWAY from Montag at the window to reveal the train suspended from overhead tracks several hundred feet the air, rocketing through canyons of downtown skyscraper one of many trains doing the same. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It's quiet and sparse compared to the city, which dominat the skyline b.g. A few video displays flicker at deserted intersections. There's not a soul in sight, except: Montag is walking home from his train stop, gym bag at hi side. He slows, hearing something strange: The sound of a CHILD SINGING. He stops, perplexed. What the hell is a child doing outsi and at this time of night? He moves to a low fence. The house beyond it is ramshackl but tidy, set back on a property overgrown and wild. As h approaches, the unseen child hears him and falls silent.
Montag peers over the fence, scanning the darkness. Nothi but bushes and trees.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Who's there? Silence. Like breath being held.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Come out where I can see you. (beat) It's all right. I'm your neighbor. I live a few doors down.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know. I've seen you walking home. CLARISSE eases from behind a tree, her face beautiful in moonlight. She's nine years old.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: You're that fireman. Montag pauses, oddly captivated by the little girl. Seein her is the last thing he expected.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You say that like it's scary.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Fireman are scary. They come at night and burn down your house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Only if you've broken the law. I'm sure you haven't. Have you? She shakes her head gravely. Montag smiles -- he was joki but the little girl's so serious he wants to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. So there's nothing to be scared of. Is there?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What are you doing out so late?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Making up songs.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Songs.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: (nods) My uncle says I'm odd.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'd have to agree. A POLICE CAR appears, pinning Montag in its spotlight as turns and shields his eyes. Clarisse ducks, unseen behind fence, light spilling through the cracks in the boards. T COPS are faceless behind the glare:

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Identify.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Guy Montag. Fireman. District four. dust heading home from my shift.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: A dash-mounted PLASMA SCREEN echoes Montag's words, produ a wave pattern I.D. match. The screen brings up Montag's

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Have a good one. The spotlight kicks off and the cruiser moves on.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: That's your name? Mr. Montag? I'm Clarisse.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Clarisse. Montag resumes walking slowly along the fence. Clarisse k pace with him on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Do you like being a fireman?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Of course I do. What kind of question is that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: I'm just wondering. I never spoke to a fireman before. Do you ever read the books you burn?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. That's against the law. Even for firemen.  Montag stops

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: But you still like it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We protect people. Keep them safe. People like you. Your mom and dad. Your uncle.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: He was arrested once for being a pedestrian.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: He must have been doing something aside from walking.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: No, just walking. My uncle's odd, too. He says it runs in the family.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What else does your uncle say?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: He says once upon a time firemen used to put out fires. Is that true? short, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. He's making that up. (beat) You should go back inside. Your parents will worry.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: They don't mind. They say it's safer at night. Because of the curfews. So I come out in the yard sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: It's nice at night, 'cause it's so quiet. I like to smell things. And look at things. Sometimes if you look real hard, there's a man in the moon.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You mean the mining colonies?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: No, silly, a man. You can see his face, there on the moon.
He stops, stares up at the full moon, but:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I don't see him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: He's there. You have to look hard.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Clarisse! A MAN emerges in the darkness, coming from the house.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Come away from there. You shouldn't be talking to strangers.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: It's our neighbor, Mr. Montag. The man pauses, dappled in shadow, eyeing Montag with cau

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Please excuse my daughter. She's very young.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No harm done.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Come along, Clarisse. It's late. He takes her hand and pulls her away. As they head off to the house, Clarisse looks back:

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Mx. Montag? Are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That's enough now. Time for bed. They vanish across the darkness of the lawn. Montag stand gazing after them, flummoxed by the encounter. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Am I happy? He moves on...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-and enters in darkness. He deposits his gym bag, hangs fireman's jacket, muttering:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that?
‘He proceeds into --

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: -- where he pulls a Ready Meal from the freezer and pops in the microwave. The microwave emits a three-second puls

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Of course I'm happy. ...and he pulls the meal out, now piping hot. He pops the lid, blows on it, grabs a fork... ...and exits into the hallway, eating, careful not to bur his mouth. He moves up the darkened hallway toward CANNED VOICES and flickering light coming from the TV room.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie? Honey? I'm home...

dialogues.speaker: THE TV ROOM
dialogues.text: The room is a TV, the plasma screen walls creating a comp visual wrap-around. Some banal infotainment program is pl peddling trivialities and flashy visuals to an empty room

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: off. The room goes dark. Montag proceeds up the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Montag enters. It, too, seems empty. As he turns to leave his foot hits something, sends it rolling across the floo It's a pill bottle. Empty. Montag stares down at it, tryi to divine its meaning. He turns back into the room, sees: A woman's pale foot lying on the floor past the bed. He darts past the bed and finds MILLIE sprawled unconscio vomit staining her mouth and pooling on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: ..oh, God... He goes to his knees, checking her pulse.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie! Millie! (shouting) Dial medical emergency!

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: Dialing. Panicking, Montag pulls her to a sitting position and get his fingers in her mouth, trying to clear the vomit.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Honey. Honey, it's me. Breathe. Breathe.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Medical 911. All our lines are busy. Please stay on the--

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Cancel! Damn it! Desperate, moving fast, Montag pulls Millie to her feet a slings her arm around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Dial Captain Beatty! Home number!

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: Dialing. CAMERA FOLLOWS HANDHELD as he pulls her to the bedroom do and walks/drags her up the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: C'mon, Millie. C'mon, baby. Can you hear my voice?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Captain! It's Montag!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Montag? What's the problem, you sound strange... Montag gets to the bathroom, pulls Millie inside...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I need help! It's my wife! She's sick! I...I think she's overdosed on levelers and I can't get through on the emergency lines! (to the sink) Water! Cold! +..and the faucet starts. He leans her over the sink, spl her face, sailing on adrenaline and panic as:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Hold on. I'll use my priority code. I'll be off the line a moment. A CLICK. Montag keeps splashing her face, cleaning the vo from her mouth. He lets her sag, lays her down on the flo

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Breathe, honey, breathe. ...and starts giving her mouth-to-mouth, trying to clear breathing passage. She's choking, floundering.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, goddamn it, BREATHE! Another CLICK as Beatty comes back on the line:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Hang in there, Montag. Help's on the way.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A WHINE OF TURBINES descends from above, rippling the air with heat signature exhaust. Montag rushes outside as a H AMBULANCE drops from the sky and touches down.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The MEDICS rush Millie outside on a gurney with Montag at their heels.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The gurney is slid into the bay and the MEDICAL TEAM goes work. Automated systems engage. Imaging scanners sweep he body. Needles descend on robotic arms, find her veins, pi her skin to draw blood. Plasma screens activate as:

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Subject. Mildred Evers Montag. Okay, let's see some history here... (rapping the touchscreen) Piece of crap, c'mon. Millie's info appears, scrolling. The medic works the touchscreen, everything moving fast:

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: No pre-existing conditions...no medication allergies...

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Blood analysis?

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Levelers, big-time. Plus a little vodka. She's floating. A probe is used to clear her trachea. A hose is fed down throat, the stomach pump engaged. The contents of her sto are hosed into a clear plastic bag as:

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Get that adrenaline into her! Get those scrubbers going! More pumps activate. The blood starts draining from her b via tubes, then run through a system of spinning filters re-deposited in her veins. Things start to calm as:

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Okay, let the machine do its work. Couple of cycles should do it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: is watching the whole thing through the rear doors of the ambulance. Medic #1 steps down and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Her vital signs are coming up. She'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Are we taking her to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Nah, this is outpatient stuff, we do it all the time. Recycle her blood, she'll be fine. She'll sleep like crazy, though, so don't let that scare you. It's normal. He moves off. Montag watches his unconscious wife lying t as the machines hum. The POLICE CAR reappears:

dialogues.speaker: EFFECT. RETURN TO YOUR HOMES... ,
dialogues.text: Montag turns, sees groups of NEIGHBORS watching from the sidewalks up and down the street. They turn and head back into their homes. Montag looks to Clarisse's house. She and her family are watching from their porch. They're at a distance, but eve from here Montag can feel the little girl's gaze as we

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag awakens to find Millie's side of the bed empty...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: ...and he emerges from the bedroom. The TV room is alread on, but also empty. He continues up the hallway to --

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: -- where he finds Millie making breakfast, pale and drawn drifting like a ghost. PLASMA TVs are playing in here, to drawing her attention as:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey. You overslept.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (watching her carefully) How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Hungry. I don't know why I'm so hungry. I'm starving. (looks to him) Did we have people over last night?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Some people came.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm so hung over. I remember somebody talking to me. Saying something. I hope I didn't make a fool of myself.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie...about last night...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Why'd you let me drink so much? I've got this taste in my mouth. Ugh...did I throw up? Did anybody see?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, listen... Suddenly, a SOFT VOICE announces:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Montag. It's time for the Family. Mrs. Montag...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: The Family's here. Let's talk about this tonight. Hurrying now, she gathers her tray, pauses --

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: You okay? You look terrible. -- and exits into the hallway. Montag follows her.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We should talk about this now.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Honey, it's the Family. And you have to get ready for work. We'll talk tonight. She enters:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No we won't. There'll be some other program on tonight. Montag hovers in the doorway as she heads to her favorite chair, one that swivels 360 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm here!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ...welcome you again to the warm bosom of the Family. Bringing you love, life, commitment...all the things you treasure most...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, please...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Honey, shhh. I never miss the Family, you know that... We're suddenly surrounded on all sides by a beach. The di clarity of the image is stunning, the enveloping 360 so convincing it's almost as if we've been transported there The FIVE CHARACTERS on the plasma screens are life-sized, walking along the surf, talking earnestly:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to be controlling, but I am her father.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I agree. This is a huge decision that will affect her entire life.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: But it's her life, let's not forget that. We can't live it for her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Of course. But we are a family, and I feel it bears discussion. What do you think, Millie? The characters hit a cue-loop and stop, looking at Millie awaiting her answer. This is an interactive soap opera:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, of course I agree. It certainly bears discussion. The characters resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Thank you, Millie. We can always count on you to be the voice of reason.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Millie dear. You are such a comfort to this family.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (beaming) I'm always so happy to help.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Now, Jenny...about this marriage proposal...what do we really know about this fellow...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You took all the pills in your bottle last night.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (distracted) What?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Your levelers. You took them all. On screen, the characters pause, looking again to Millie:

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Millie...did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: No, no...please continue.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You had to have your stomach pumped and your blood recycled.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. I wouldn't do a thing like that.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: (pausing) What's ridiculous, Millie dear?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (to the screen) Just ignore me. I'm talking to myself. Please continue.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: He's from an excellent family, but what does it matter? I'm so in love, I've never felt this way before...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: But you did. The bottle was empty.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: That's not possible. I wouldn't do that. Why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Maybe you took a few and forgot. Then took a few more.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: That's stupid. I didn't. Why would

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm asking.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't. Not in a billion years. She's distracted, trying to follow the discussion on scre Montag comes up behind her, trying to get her attention:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Am I lying to you? Millie? Is that what you think? That I'd look you in the eye and lie to you? He puts his hand on her shoulder, but she slaps it away:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: No! You're just wrong! You're being stupid, so stop it! Let me watch my program! I'm missing what they're saying!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: ...mMost precious thing in the world. Don't you want for my happiness? Don't you, Millie? Don't you think I should have Tyler's baby?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: O£ course. Of course you should. I want you to be so happy.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (tears glistening) Oh, thank you, Millie. I love you so. It'll be perfect, you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (to Bob) Millie is the wise one in the family. She's never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: I don't want to ruin anybody's happiness, but there's one thing we haven't considered...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (softly) I gotta get ready for work. Millie's no longer listening. Montag drifts from the room

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A cold breeze rattles the autumn leaves across the paveme as Montag walks toward the transit station with his gym b He slows in front of Clarisse's house, gazing over the fe across the wild tangle of yard. Curious about the house a the people who live there.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Clarisse is attending home school, using'a stylus on an electronic pad to do her lessons. Through the window, b.g the tiny figure of Montag can be seen on the street. Clarisse notices Montag out there, pauses the lesson.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag sees her appear at the window. She gives him a ten smile and a wave. Hesitant, Montag waves back. Clarisse motions "wait" and disappears from view. A momen later she reappears with a CAT, an orange tabby, and puts on the inner sill. Montag watches, increasingly puzzled. The cat patiently endures as Clarisse puts a little red c hat on him with a rubber band strap, then slips his hind into little cowboy boots. Done, Clarisse stands the kitty on its hind legs and "puppets" him in a goofy little danc The image is so absurd and unexpected, Montag can't help laughing. Clarisse smiles at his reaction, happy. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Now that's just...silly. She makes the cat wave goodbye. Montag walks on... CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -and we're plunged into a cauldron of NOISE: Firemen shou as bets are made, insults traded. DILLMAN, LANDERS, PECK, ORMSBY, and a DOZEN OTHERS are clustered around six wire on the firehouse floor, each containing a LARGE SEWER RAT Before them stands the Mechanical Hound, waiting. As the men jostle and shout, Dillman raises a cage to sho everybody the aggressive, hissing rat within. The cage ha handwritten number "3" on it.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: Who's it gonna be? Horse number three? Let's see some money!

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Look at that mean son of a bitch! That's him, that's my bad boy!

dialogues.speaker: LANDERS
dialogues.text: You're gonna lose your shirt, Peck!

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Fifty bucks says you can kiss my ass!

dialogues.speaker: LANDERS
dialogues.text: A bargain! Your wife charges a hundred!

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Go on, Dillman, give it a whiff! Dillman holds the cage out, letting the Mechanical Hound the rat. To a nose as finely calibrated as the Hound's, t rat's scent is as good as a DNA fingerprint. (The data ap on Ormsby's plasma-screen next to "Horse #3: Peck's Bad B

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Got it! Next! Dillman dumps the rat out of the cage to join two others already in the "starting gate" -- a round bottomless hold pen on the floor. He reaches for the next cage while:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG AND BEATTY
dialogues.text: sit on a cot apart from the others, speaking quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Thank you for helping last night.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I came close to losing her. If you hadn't intervened...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: And how's Millie? Okay? (Montag hesitates) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: She won't talk about it. She won't even admit it happened.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Maybe that's a good thing. If she doesn't remember, I doubt she intended to harm herself. That's what's got you worried, yes? (Montag nods) She probably just lost track. It happens. Never happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: . MONTAG
dialogues.text: I don't take levelers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Really? I never knew that. Montag, I'm surprised at you. It's the shortcut to bliss, haven't you seen the ads? Everybody takes levelers.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (wry) I like a little misery now and again. (Montag laughs softly) Ah, a smile, thank God. There's the old Montag. I was beginning to worry. Dillman dumps the last rat into the holding pen, raises h arms to quiet the men:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: Welcome to Rat Dome! Six rats enter...one rat leaves! Mr. Ormsby, program the Hound for five kills in random order, if you please! Who will the lucky survivor be? Final bets, place your final bets! (calls over) Montag, you in?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: (offering) And we know our dear captain never wagers...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I prefer sure things to guesswork. But thank you, Mr. Dillman.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: In that case, the betting window is closed! Horses are at the gate! A boisterous countdown begins:

dialogues.speaker: FIVE. ..FOUR...THREE...TWO...ONE
dialogues.text: Dillman kicks the holding pen over, freeing the rats --

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: And they're off! -- which scatter in all directions, men jumping and shout as rats go zipping past their feet. Ormsby hits "send." The Hound's eyes go infra-red. Pandem ensues as the Hound springs into action and streaks acros the firehouse like a guided missile...

...and catches the first rat within seconds, snatching it in its jaws and shaking its chrome head so fast that the flies apart in its teeth. (That rat's data entry turns re Ormsby's screen.) The Hound veers and goes after the next rat, men running and shouting and jumping out of the way

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: It's not just the incident last night, is it? There's something else troubling you.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We don't seem to talk much at all any more. I feel like we've drifted, but...I don't know why. Or what to do about it. I try.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUND
dialogues.text: makes another kill. Another entry on Ormsby's screen turn red. The men shout like spectators at a football game.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can make our human resources department available to you. Therapy, counseling...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Those benefits are for ranking officers only.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn't going to spill these beans just yet...

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUND
dialogues.text: kills another rat, veers after the next.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ++. but I've decided to nominate you as my replacement when I retire. That means promotion. Captain Montag, how does that sound? I'll suggest they advance you some of those benefits. With your record, and your promising future, I'm sure DHS will see things my way. Montag is blown away by this news. Beatty leans in.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: You're special, Montag. Command caliber. That makes you a deeply valuable asset to this department.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Someday, my boy, all this will be yours. Including the rats... (his gaze shifts) .--oh, hell. A rat zips under their cot, the Hound in pursuit. They le to their feet as the Hound barrels between them, sending cot spinning into the air to the delighted howls of the m We hear a SQUEAL as the fifth rat is killed. Its data ent goes red, leaving one. The Hound pauses, awaiting further instructions. Amidst the jeers and laughter:

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Too bad, Peck. That was your bad boy. Peck bends down and sees the sixth and final rat pressed against the wall under a desk, panting in terror.

dialogues.speaker: LANDERS
dialogues.text: And the winner is?

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Horse #2, "Dillman's Delight."

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: Ohhh, what a heartbreak! Sorry, boys, fork it over! I hate to say it, but I am the winnaahh...

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Take your money and shut your pie- hole, Dillman. Suddenly, the ALARM SOUNDS. The men react, scattering as:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, fun's over! Kindly dispose of the winner. Ormsby quickly enters a kill command. The Hound bounds ac the floor and pounces on the last SHRIEKING rat as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: HUGE DOORS slide open, revealing the Salamander in a glar lights. It rumbles out, SIREN WAILING. The control van fo

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A three-story Victorian relic stands like a ghost from an era just outside the downtown financial district, skyscra looming in the misty sky b.g. The vacant lots in this area have become Hoovervilles of future -- shanty towns filled with HOMELESS PEOPLE living tents and cardboard boxes. Cookfires are drifting smoke. Searchlights suddenly blaze from the sky as HOVERCOPTERS appear. The homeless begin to panic as the SIREN of the Salamander comes swelling up the street.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: (from hovercopter)

dialogues.speaker: THE SALAMANDER
dialogues.text: pulls up before the Victorian house. The control van veer past it, taking up position as police vehicles arrive to provide backup. Some of the homeless start drifting this from their shanty towns, drawn by the promise of a fire. Firemen jump down from the truck, marching across the str of dead lawn past a PAIR OF STONE LIONS. This house might have been a library once, a few hundred years ago. The battering rams are readied as the men take positions the door. Beatty knocks. For a moment there's nothing. Be is about to motion them to break the door down, but then: A face appears at the window, ethereal and beautiful. It' OLD WOMAN, her eyes luminous, her skin like worn silk. She motions for Beatty to be patient. The face withdraws. few seconds pass. We hear the door UNLOCKING from inside. It opens, revealing the old woman. Her smile is enigmatic if she's merely receiving visitors.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Madam. We have a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Everything all nice and legal and proper. Nobody's rights shall be violated this evening, I'm sure. (swings the door wider) Please do come in. Mind you wipe your feet. Montag and the others are trading glances. This is differ

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The firemen enter and spread out a bit, gazing up. We're grand entry foyer that soars three stories up, surrounded all sides by landings. The staircase railings are carved the lighting is Tiffany stained glass, the furnishings ar ancient as the house. A grandfather clock TICKS SOFTLY.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: I've been expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Have you indeed?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: For many years. I've often tried to imagine your face. Now I know. Beatty raises his plasma-screen clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: You may call me Mrs. Havisham, if that pleases you. And I might call you Pip. Yes, that might be quite amusing. (off his look) Don't insult my intelligence. You know my name.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (checks his screen) Mrs. Roland. I am Captain Beatty. We've received an anonymous tip...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Is there any other kind?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ...which empowers us by law to conduct a search for books.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: And you shall find them, I'm sure. In the walls. The attic. Under the floors. Don't forget to check the cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Montag. Have the men proceed, and see the lady out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Five teams of three! Carillo, Peck, first and second floors! Dillman, third! Landers, basement! Ormsby, attic! Go! The teams split up, double-timing. The old woman watches go. Montag offers his hand to escort her out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Please come with me.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: I most certainly will not. Nor may you coerce me. Isn't that right, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Dear lady, let's have no foolishness. Accompany the fireman, he'll see you safely out. Please don't make me insist.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Insist all you like. I am perfectly within my legal rights, as you well know. Montag throws Beatty a puzzled look. Beatty gives the old woman an appraising look, motions Montag to wait.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: According to whom? She pulls a book from her pocket, paging through it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Your own Homeland Security manual. One of the few books not on the burning list. I've read it many times with great interest, especially the section on your department. (pauses to read) "The fire department was established in 1790 to burn English-influenced ° (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: books in the Colonies. The first fireman: Benjamin Franklin." Oh, I do so love history. (keeps paging) Let's see. Ah, here it is. I have it marked. Chapter twelve, subsection four. According to the Supreme Court decision granting the government full authority as regards the burning of books for purposes of national security, the accused -- that would be me -- has the right to remain present and bear full witness. She closes the book and tucks it away.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That's an extremely obscure and seldom-invoked right .

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I invoke it. {off Beatty's look) They're your rules. You must abide by them. A moment of stand-off. Beatty gazing at the woman. The wo unflinching. Montag uncertain, caught between them.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Montag. Scan the lady, if you please. Montag pulls his x-ray wand, running it up and down the w body. Beatty clicks his comlink...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Control?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -..and we see x-ray images coming over the monitors -- bo veins, swirls of cloth. The computers give readouts and percentages: "Cotton Fiber, Elastics, Organic Material,"

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: No concealed weapons...no incendiary devices...

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: (over comlink, filtered) -.-She's clean.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: You may stay until I order in the flamethrowers. That is when your right expires and you shall be removed for your own safety. Until then, Fireman Montag will remain at your side.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: That is satisfactory. Montag shakes his head -- this is crazy. Beatty glances u a VOICE comes over his comlink:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: (filtered) Cap! You're not gonna believe this...

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR
dialogues.text: Dillman and his team are sweeping the hallway walls with wands, mouths agape, the ghostly x-ray images revealing: Books. And more books. Endless rows of them within the wa

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The controllers are watching, amazed. The monitors show x images of books everywhere throughout the house. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Holy Christ. Look at ‘em all.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Dillman appears at the third floor railing above.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: They're everywhere. The whole house...

dialogues.speaker: LANDER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over comlink, filtered) Landers, sir, confirming that. Must be thousands.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Get on with it. AXES AND CHAINSAWS rip the walls... CEILINGS are torn open with long pikes... FLOORBOARDS are sundered with pry bars... SHELVES are overturned, furniture smashed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: replays the opening image of our film: In SLO-MO, an object falls through frame -- a book. Rolli tumbling, dropping from sight. Another book. And another. Books falling. And soon: Raining. It's raining books. ANGLE TILTS DOWN to reveal t old woman watching the books falling all around her. She to Montag, meets his gaze. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Why do you want to see this?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: They're my books. Montag catches a book as it falls, looks up to see:

dialogues.speaker: FIREMEN
dialogues.text: throwing armloads of books over the railings. They rain d cascading, fluttering like birds. Montag takes the old wo by the elbow, guides her gently to a safer position...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-while the Scooper dumps another load of books onto the beacon and backs away...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-.and boots come pounding as firemen enter with kerosen pumpers on their backs, fanning out. ANGLE SHIFTS TO Montag watching the old woman. She's taki it all in, her expression inscrutable... All around them, throughout the house, firemen soak the w the heaps of books, priming the house like a bomb... The fumes are getting thick. Montag snaps his breather ma over his face, takes a few deep breaths. He pulls the mas away, offers it to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: No thank you. She pulls a handkerchief, holds it over her nose and mout A few firemen are gathering at Beatty's side, pumpers emp Montag, cued by a look from Beatty, clicks his comlink:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, wrap it up.

dialogues.speaker: UPPER FLOOR
dialogues.text: Dillman's pumper goes dry. He motions "let's go" to the o as he clicks his comlink:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: We're done here! Heading down now!

dialogues.speaker: ENTRYWAY
dialogues.text: Beatty turns to the old woman:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: The flamethrowers are next. It's time to leave. She meets his gaze, her eyes watering from the fumes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: You can't ever have my books.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (gently) Books aren't real. Only the law is real. Come on now.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'd rather stay.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: You know I can't allow that. Suicide is also against the law.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Ma'am. This whole house is gonna go up. Come on. I'll walk you out.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: . CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I'm counting to ten. If you don't leave, my men will pick you up and carry you out. One...two...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: It'll be okay. Just come with me.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ...three...four...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ...five...six...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (offering his hand) Please.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Go on. I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: ...seven...eight...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: .-Shut the gate... She reaches up, undoing her bun. Her hair unravels as she pulls a small, slender object from it...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: ..-nine...ten... ...and she holds the object out toward them...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: ..a big fat hen. ---it's an ordinary kitchen match. Her thumbnail poised o the sulfur tip. The men draw back, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Panic erupts, voices shouting and overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: --where the hell did that come from--

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: --get 'em out, get 'em out of there--

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: (on comlink) --all personnel evacuate the building immediately! Suspect has a match...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: FIREMEN react, horrified, breaking and running for the ex

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: (on comlink, filtered) ..-repeat, suspect has a match! Evacuate the building now!

dialogues.speaker: GRAND ENTRYWAY
dialogues.text: ...while the old woman backs Montag, Beatty, and the othe firemen toward the door with her match.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: {calm, steely) Gentlemen, you heard the order. Evacuate. The others rush out, but Montag stays. He and Beatty keep backing slowly toward the door as:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Allow me to appeal to your reason. Where's the sense in this?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where's the sense in anything? The world's gone upside down.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: The world is fine, it's your mind that's upside down. See what those books have done to you?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Ma'am. This is crazy. You don't want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: This is my home. And these are my books. Get out. Now. (as they hesitate)

dialogues.speaker: GET THE HELL OUT
dialogues.text: Montag and Beatty back out the door...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: ...onto the front porch. A VOICE comes over Beatty's coml

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) The police have a sniper! Should we take her out? Beatty throws Montag a long-suffering look, clicks his co

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That would defeat the purpose now, wouldn't it? I'm certain Mrs. Roland will see reason, once she's had a chance to think it through. Isn't that right, dear? The old woman turns away, walking back to the center of t xoom, gazing around at the wreckage, the piles of books. tries to go back inside to grab her, but Beatty puts a restraining hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Roland? You've made your point. Given everyone a good scare. Well done. Time to come out now. She turns, facing them. A long look passes between them a her thumbnail tightens on the match head...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Play the man, Master Ridley; we shall this day light such a candle, by God's grace, in England, as I trust shall never be put out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Don't. ---and her thumbnail scrapes the sulfur tip, FLARING it t life. Montag's eyes widen in horror -- -- and the match flare leaps into the air, a heartbeat of white-hot ignition, the air rippling as it catches fire. a moment the old woman is surrounded by an aura of flame swirling about her, lifting her hair and catching it afir making her eyes glow like coals -- -- and BOOOOM! The entryway EXPLODES, shattering windows, HUGE FIST OF FLAME punching through the front door and bl Beatty and Montag right off their feet, hurling them over railings and onto the lawn in a storm of debris. Some oth firemen are caught on the run, also blown off their feet.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A firestorm surges up the stairs...races along the walls...engulfing room after room...shattering the grandf clock with heat...consuming piles of books...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag pries his face off the lawn, sees Beatty sitting u next to him with his pant leg on fire. Frantic, Montag he smother the flames as Beatty yells into his comlink:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Did everybody get out?

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: (filtered) All links are active! Everybody's fine! Montag turns, gazing at the house through a pall of smoke swirling embers, and sees:

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: An inferno within. A FIGURE appears in the flames. A burn woman. Staggering in the blast-furnace. Tripping and fall Then gone in a rush of flame.

dialogues.speaker: PUSH IN ON MONTAG
dialogues.text: staring in horror.

dialogues.speaker: FIREMEN
dialogues.text: come running against a backdrop of flames, pulling Beatty Montag to their feet, rushing them away as the house burn

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Riding back to the firehouse. Faces grim.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Gear is being cleaned and stowed. The mood is subdued, qu Montag backs the Scooper off the firetruck, parks it. As gets off, Beatty enters and activity comes to a standstil

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Most of you have never seen a suicide. They were far more common in the old days. Just understand there is no accounting for unstable minds. You all followed protocol and did your jobs well. Nobody here is to blame. Glances are traded. Nobody feels good about what happened tonight. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I missed it. The match. When I scanned her.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Then it's your fault? I see. Or is it mine, for failing to instruct you to scan her hair? I was officer in charge, after all. Blame, if any, lies with me. My report will say so. But Montag. I was not the old woman who stood in a house primed with kerosene and chose to light a match. Nor were you. Nor (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: were any of us. That act of insanity lies solely with her. Yes? Montag nods. Beatty motions to the group.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Let's put it behind us. That gear isn't going to stow itself, is it? The men disperse, activity resuming as:

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: (grumbling) I dunno what we're all twisted up over. Stupid old bitch could'a got us all killed. I'm glad she burned.

dialogues.speaker: LANDERS
dialogues.text: Leave it alone, Peck. Give us a break...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: secures the Scooper, attaching the tiedowns, as Beatty co up behind him:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: All done?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I still have to recharge the fuel cells.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: No. I mean, blaming yourself. All done? . Montag hesitates, nods. Beatty starts to move off, but:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Master Ridley. That crazy thing she said. Play the game, something, something.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: "Play the man, Master Ridley. We shall this day light such a candle, by God's grace, in England, as I trust shall never be put out." Some firemen nearby pause, startled.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: A man named Latimer said that to a man named Nicholas Ridley as they were being burnt alive at Oxford, for heresy, in 1555. (off their looks) Oh, I'm full of bits and pieces. Most fire captains are, after doing it enough years. The nonsense sticks to your boots like chewing gum. (to Montag) But nonsense is all it is. Romantic, foolish notions that appeal to feeble minds and justify idiot behavior such as suicide. (leans in, softly) Go home, Montag. Hug your wife. Beatty departs. Montag moves to the front of the Scooper connect the hydrogen fuel hose... ---and stops. There, lying in the scoop blade, are TWO BO that _got left behind when the last load was dumped.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: . (suddenly appears) Need help?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Um...no. Got it. Thanks. Ormsby leaves. Montag connects the fuel coupling, moves o

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -.,and we find Montag sitting before his locker after a s toweling his hair. He looks numb. The place is emptying, doors shutting, voices drifting off, firemen heading home He becomes aware of Dillman down the row, lacing his boot look passes between them. It's clear both men are stunned deeply shaken. Softly, so only Montag can hear:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: I can't get it out of my head. You? Montag shakes his head. No, he can't. Almost embarrassed, Dillman grabs his gym bag and leaves. Montag is left alone. He rises to his locker, lifts his fireman's necklace from its peg, drapes it around his nec CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag slides down the brass pole, moves through the shad past the Salamander. This part of the firehouse is desert MUFFLED VOICES can be heard from the floor above, followe occasional bursts of raucous laughter. Montag's drawn inexorably to the Scooper. He stops, peers into the scooper blade, sees the two books lying in shado He's frozen, unsure. He reaches in and pulls one out. It' "Charlie the Choo Choo," by Beryl Evans. A children's boo He pulls out the other one. "Lord of the Flies," by Willi Golding. Neither title means anything to him, but the boo themselves have him transfixed. Quickly, before he can change his mind, he shoves the boo into his gym bag, heads for the exit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and as he rounds the corner, comes face to face with t Mechanical Hound. The beast is lying there, head resting its paws. Montag freezes. The Hound raises its head, looking like an exotic chromed Sphinx. Its glowing red eyes abruptly dilate wider with a soft WHIRRR. To Montag's astonishment, a LOW GROWL builds the Hound's throat.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Easy, boy. Easy now. Montag takes a nervous step back. The Hound rises and com forward, sniffing the air... Its titanium jaws open, gleaming. The hypodermic tongue distends, slowly at first, then flicking forward and back forward and back -- snap, snap, snap! A drop of amber flu flies off the needle tip, hits the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: sit. Goddamn it, I said sit. The Hound hesitates, backs off. Its haunches lower and th beast lies back down, but remains coiled like a spring.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Good boy. Stay. Stay. The Hound stays. Montag circles past it, out the door...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The latest war news is playing on the VID SCREENS. Images floating HOVERTANKS skimming desert sands in some far off land. Muzzle blasts. Explosions. Stirring theme music. PAN TO Montag waiting for his train. A PAIR OF BEAT COPS their urban armor are crossing the platform toward him. T see his fireman's uniform, pass him with a nod. He nods b cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag rides the train, paranoia growing. People seem to staring at him. He turns away, looks out the window. cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag walks home, gym bag in hand. In the far b.g., a POLICE CAR appears, cruising slowly in the intersection. Montag glances back and keeps walking, praying the car will continue on through the intersection But no, the police car turns, coming this way. Montag kee walking, slowly, forcing himself to appear nonchalant. Bu the moment he turns the corner...

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT STREET
dialogues.text: ..-he breaks into a full run. Feet pounding the pavement, bag flying at his side. He drops the gym bag. Shit! He skids to a stop, grabs it, goes darting down the next intersecting street. A moment later, the police car appears around the corner. pedestrian they were tailing is gone. The car accelerates toward us, LIGHTS FLASHING...

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT STREET
dialogues.text: ..as Montag comes running, hearing the police car racing toward the intersection behind him. He dives for cover behind some trash cans lining the side squeezing into the shadows between the cans and a fence. The police car swerves into view around the corner. Slowi SPOTLIGHTS blaze to life as the vehicle comes creeping up street toward us, probing the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON MONTAG
dialogues.text: as the lights grow brighter, nearer. He's gasping to catc his breath. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whispering) Don't breathe so loud. They have microphones. Montag turns his head. The fence he's squeezed up against Clarisse's. He can see her eyes through the cracks in the boards -- she's crouched on the other side. The car draws parallel with them, the dazzling glare of t spotlight probing from the other side of the trash cans. The car stops. Faint, ghostly RADIO CHATTER spills into t night. We hear murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: I got sound and motion. Something back there. Montag's frozen, trying not to move or breathe. Suddenly, from the other side of the fence comes a MEOW. Clarisse's skitters along the fence in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Goddamn cat. The car moves on, spotlight plying the shadows. Montag wa it disappear down the street. In whispers:

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Why are you hiding?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I did something tonight. Something very stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I took some books. No response at first. He shifts his head so he can see he more clearly through the slats in the fence. She's watchi him, her face like a porcelain doll's in the moonlight .

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Did you? Did you really?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: It was stupid. I shouldn't have done it. And I shouldn't have run ‘just now. I'ma fireman, they wouldn't have searched me. I'm not thinking clearly. I have to think. He hugs the gym bag to his chest, mind racing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'll just give them back. Better yet, burn them. That's right, that's what I should do. Just tear out the pages and burn them myself.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Yes. That would probably be best. (pause) Can I see them? He hesitates, opens the gym bag, pulls out the books. She reaches through the slats, fingertips brushing the covers

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: "Charlie the Choo Choo." ,

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: If they ever found out...if they knew I had them...

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: I won't tell. Montag's shocked. Her words, so simple, have unlocked a door...as if she, of all people, had given him permission

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You won't?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Not anybody. Not ever. He peers at her through the slats.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Really? She nods, her expression grave. Montag doesn't know what say. He looks down at the books, makes a decision. He eases "Charlie the Choo Choo" through the slats. Clari breath catches in her throat. She takes the book, almost to touch it. She looks to him, unable to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Make sure nobody finds that. I mean ever, ever. Okay? She draws the book toward her, but hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: It's not a trick, is it? You won't come and burn our house, will you?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. I won't. I promise. (beat) Clarisse. I'm really glad you're my friend. Really glad. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: Okay. And then she's gone, off into the shadows. Montag shoves of the Flies" back in his bag, leaves his hiding place...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Millie's asleep in the dark. Montag eases onto the bed, s fully dressed, spoons up next to her. He's uncertain, sca needing to hold her. She stirs, groggy, half-asleep, as:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We burned a woman tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: You...what? You did what?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: An old woman. She had a match. We didn't see it until it was too late.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: So...she killed herself. She was crazy. A crazy old woman.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess that's right. A crazy old woman.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: You had me confused. (rolls away) Poor Guy. You must be tired. Try and get some sleep. She drifts off. Montag holds her a while, then eases to h side of the bed, mind going a mile-a-minute.

dialogues.speaker: THE BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Montag enters, locks the door. He pulls "Lord of the Flie from his gym bag, examining it with fascination. He opens riffles the pages.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Paper. Ink. Words. So what? He sits, using the toilet for a chair, starts reading the very first page as we

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The ANGLE hasn't changed, but we find Montag sprawled on floor in an exhausted sleep, the book lying nearby. Sudden POUNDING wrenches him awake. Millie" s muffled VOI heard through the door:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Guy, answer me! Are you all right in there?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Wha--yeah...yeah, m'all right... He sits up, trying to get his bearings, reeling from bein jolted from a deep sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there? Open the door! His eyes focus, remembering where he is, sees the book ly on the floor. He grabs it and rises, fighting panic. MONTAG . Uh-huh, 'kay, just a minute...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, now! I mean it! You've been in there all morning! You got me worried sick...and I have to pee! He jams the book in his waistband, hides it with his untu shirt. A quick glance in the mirror -- yup, he looks like hell. He opens the door. Millie muscles past him and make beeline for the toilet, sitting to pee.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: -+-as Montag moves into the hallway, heart still pounding

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Were you in here all night?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry. I was throwing up. I've come down with something. (beat) Would you call Captain Beatty and tell him I'm not coming in? The DOORBELL RINGS. He starts up the hallway to answer it

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You can tell him yourself. That's probably him. ..-and he stops in his tracks, fully awake now, staring a the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What? We hear the TOILET FLUSH. Millie exits the bathroom, sees Montag standing there. The DOORBELL RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: He called twice this morning, said he was coming over. You gonna answer it? He turns, pushes past her toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. Tell him I'm sick. Tell him to go away.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: What? I can't tell him that! He's your boss!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm in bed! I've got chills! Fever! Just do it! Off her stunned look, he enters --

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
