dialogues.text: -- where he pulls the book and shoves it under his pillow He glances through the half-open bedroom door as he peels his clothes. He can see Millie at the far end of the hall b.g., talking to Beatty at the front door. She brings him this way. Montag jumps into bed. Moments l Beatty enters, trailed tentatively by Millie.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear you're sick.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I wanted to call. Ask for the night off.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: By all means, take it. Your health is important. Beatty pulls up a chair, sits at bedside, eyeing Montag.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Montag. Do take good care of our boy. Lots of rest, lots of fluids. We want him hale and hearty. She circles the bed, playing the good wife, putting on a of making Montag more comfortable, straightening the bedd

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: That's fine, honey, thanks. ..-but she keeps on fussing, cowed by Beatty's presence a

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I was worried about you. You and Dillman. You two seemed to take it the hardest. You know, he didn't go home last night. Montag's distracted and edgy -- now Millie's fluffing the damn pillows.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Honey, it's fine, okay? Dillman? What about him?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: He's gone missing. His wife says he never showed up. (off Montag's look) We've notified the police. I do hope he's okay. Montag's getting panicky as Millie tries to get at his pi to fluff it...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Honey, move your shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, leave it! It's fine!
...and she suddenly freezes, hand under his pillow, shock creeping into her face. She can feel the book. Quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Honey, the pillow's fine. We're talking. Please stop fussing. She pulls her hand away, face slack, trying not to betray anything. Beatty's watching them both as:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. How about some tea?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: That'd be great.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Captain? For you?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Splendid, thank you. She moves stiffly to the door and exits. Beatty seems to right through Montag, then:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I know what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Some firemen see a woman burn and think, "well, that happened." They go home, have dinner, show up for work the next day. It's not so easy for others. Some firemen can hit a snag from time to time. A crisis. Doubts. Questions. It's ingrained in the job. That's why I'm here, to help you through it, if I can.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Beatty slots his security card into the TV port.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Request clearance for private uplink.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: State name, rank, and division for voice recognition.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Beatty, Tiberius, fire captain, Phoenix Division.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Uplink approved. Stand by. Beatty motions for Montag to sit. Montag, in his robe, ta center seat. Beatty remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Where did it begin, you ask, this thing we do? How did it start? The TV room comes to life. We're surrounded by images, Mo and Beatty seemingly transported into the events on scree Book burnings. Many of these images were once black & whi but have since been digitally enhanced and colorized.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: They used to teach this stuff in the Academy. Gave the rookies a good grounding in fundamentals. Not so much anymore. Shame. As they watch: Bolsheviks burn decadent capitalist literature. The Nazi faithful hurl armloads of books onto raging bonf sending geysers of embers swirling into the air. Southern Baptists torch truckloads of Elvis and Beatles records, spicing the mix with armloads of "Catcher in the Rye," "Slaughterhouse Five," "Lolita." A veritable orgy of flame. Vonnegut. Wilde. Bradbury. Row Ellison. Shelley. Shaw. Heretics being burned at the stak

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON MONTAG
dialogues.text: gazing straight ahead. The images surround him on all sid flames flickering across his face and tattooing pinpoints fire into his eyes. From Montag's face, WE BOOM UP TO:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: It's nothing new, Montag, what we do. Admittedly, in the past, it's been unfocused. Haphazard. Disharmonious. Various special interest groups trying to get the better of other special interest groups whose special interests they disapproved of. Opinions flying like hand grenades. Books wielded like stone clubs to smash one another over the head with. Pundits flinging their precious thoughts like apes flinging feces through the bars of a cage.
Dizzying images of mass rallies. Stalin. Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Every so often a book would come along and turn the world on its ear. Marx and his manifesto. Hitler and his Kampf. Before you know it, it wasn't just books being burned. It was people. Not just a crazy old woman with a kitchen match, but by the millions. Entire cities. (to the TV) Show me London. Dresden. Tokyo. Click, click, click -- images of cities being consumed in massive firebombings.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Hiroshima. Nagasaki. Mushroom clouds suddenly rise before Montag's eyes like s being born. Beatty's pacing, watching, circling Montag.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Books are dangerous, Montag. Lethal in their power. The book burners had the right idea, of course, but they never burned right. They burned to prove some selfish point, not for the greater goal of harmony and the good of mankind. And then...then came the start of this century. And the beginning of clarity. Images of 9-11 are shocking in their ferocity. The Twin T burn, tumble, collapse...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Books were fine once upon a time, back when there was plenty of room, in the days of horse and cart. But the world became far too vast, too complex, too dangerous. Our agendas could no longer conflict, not if we were to survive. Pulling together for a common goal, that's what was required. Books and divisive philosophies need not apply. I won't stomach them for a moment, nor should you. The stakes were, and are, far too great. Millie enters with tea. Beatty takes a cup. The screens d increasingly futuristic forms of warfare in a wide variet lands. Floating hovertanks. Smarter and smarter bombs.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Peace, Montag. Harmony, Montag. Security, Montag. Happiness. (to Millie) That's what everyone wants, isn't it, dear? Haven't you heard it all your life? I want to be happy, people say. Don't you? Doesn't everyone?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, they do. I'm...I'm happy. Flustered, Millie offers the tea tray to Montag. He takes cup and she hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That's us, Montag. The Happiness Twins. The Dixie Duo, you and I. We stand against those who want everyone unhappy and divided. I don't think you realize how important you are to the survival of our society. Recite the first two articles of faith from the fireman's manual.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: "One, books erode the fundamental precept of our democracy, which is that all men are created equal. Two, books are a reflection of one man's ego, and thus by their very nature are antisocial and combative."

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: My God's better than your God. My morality is superior to yours. I disapprove of your life, your choices, your culture, your politics, your smell. A book is a loaded gun in the house next door. So? Into the incinerator with it. All men made equal. All men made happy. Blacks don't like "Little Black Sambo?" Burn it. Whites are ashamed of "Uncle Tom's Cabin?" Scorch it. "Johnny Got His Gun" demoralizing our troops and hindering the war effort? Render its ashes unto Caesar, lest the empire fall. (sits, faces Montag) We've been at war since before you and I were born. You did your military service as required, and with distinction. So did I. So must we all do our parts -- no ifs, ands, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: or maybes -- or we shall lose someday. Our country, our people, our way of life -- that's what's at stake. (to the room) Enough. The screens go dark, silent. Beatty pulls out his lighter flicks it on-off, on-off. Admiring the flame. He looks at Montag with a twinkle in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Tell you a little secret. I've read a few books in my day. I had doubts, too, as a younger man. Questions. I had to know what I was about. He draws a cigar from his inner pocket, applies the flame He puffs the Montag nods. Beatty rises

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: And the more I read, the more I did know. I came to know the face of my enemy and the truth of my calling. Books, dear Montag, say nothing. They're good for one thing. The application of heat. Four hundred and fifty one degrees Fahrenheit, to be precise. cigar to life.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: So...if a fireman were to... accidentally...not really intending anything...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Take a book home? His mouth is dry.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: A natural error. Curiosity alone. We don't get anxious or mad. We let the fireman keep the book for a day or two. If he hasn't burned it by then, well...we simply come and burn it for him. (off Montag's look) Fire is bright, and fire is clean. Feel better, my boy. I hope to see you back before too long. and exits past Millie hovering in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Thank you for the tea.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Bye. They stay frozen: Montag in the chair, Millie in the door They listen as Beatty goes to the front door and exits. Montag turns, looks to Millie. She's seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn you. She darts from view toward the bedroom. Everything that f is HANDHELD, continuous: Montag jumps up, out of the TV room, down the hallway, in the bedroom, where Millie's ripping the bedding away, hur it to the floor, grabbing the book, colliding with Montag he tries to calm her, but she's beyond that, hysterical..

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Are you insane? What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, please, listen--

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Get away from me! ..and she's up the hallway, into the bathroom, slams the door in his face. WE HOLD ON Montag in the hallway as:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie!

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not listening to you! Go away!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (beat, trying to be calm) Millie. Honey. Please don't hurt the book.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You bastard! I'm burning it!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got a lighter from the kitchen! I'm burning it!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, don't! I mean it! (pounds on the door) Millie! No response. Montag backs up a step and delivers a brutal kick. The door bursts open, lock splintering the jamb. CAMERA FOLLOWS into the bathroom, jarring and chaotic, Mi at the sink, stunned and fearful, book blazing up in her He snatches the flaming book from her, slaps the flame ou Montag's clenched, furious, tightly reined. We've never s him pissed before, but it looks like he could do some dam He pulls off the charred dustjacket, flings it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You call this a burn? It's a joke. Kerosene and a flamethrower. That's how you burn. (riffling pages) Or rip 'em out and burn 'em one by one. That what you want? Is it?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes! That's what I want! CAMERA FOLLOWS Montag from the bathroom, down the hallway

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: ‘kay, fine, but it's not the only thing we should burn around here.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (at his heels) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: If we're gonna burn, let's do it right! Start with that room, those goddamn talking walls! ..-and into the TV room, trailed by Millie.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Listen to you, you're not making sense! It's that book that's done it to you, that book...it's not real! Books aren't real!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (indicates room) And this is?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: It is! It's got light, and sound, and people laughing and talking and saying my name...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I_say your name, Millie. I say it all the time. Do you hear it? or just the goddamn "people" in the walls? Them, your "family." (closing on her) Do they love you, Millie? Do they hold you at night and listen to you sleep? Do they lie awake and worry about how many pills you took, is that why they say your name? (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (crying, helpless) I don't know what you want from me! I don't know what's happening to you! Montag pauses, calming, getting a grip. His own rage has stunned him, left him shaking.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You weren't there. You didn't see ‘ her. The woman we burned.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: The crazy woman?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: She didn't seem crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: She was! And she's made you crazy too, with this, this thing... She grabs the book from his hands. He stares at it, emoti teetering and torn.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Did you read this?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Last night. The whole thing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off her shock) I...didn't understand it. I mean, it seemed simple enough, but...1I couldn't figure out the reason for it.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: There isn't one! Captain Beatty was right! There's nothing in it! Nothing to understand! CAMERA FOLLOWS her out the door, up the hallway, Montag a her heels...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: The kitchen incinerator!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, no! -,-and he tries to grab her but she fights him off, slapp wildly, hysteria and terror breaking like a wave...

dialogues.speaker: YOU, BECAUSE YOU'VE GONE CRAZY
dialogues.text: ---and she keeps going but Montag grabs her around the wa grappling as she screams, and they trip, fall to the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -,-where the fight goes out of her and she goes limp unde his weight, her rage giving way to helpless tears:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: They're gonna come burn us. I live here too. Please.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie, shhh, it's okay. His grip goes gentle, caressing now, stroking her hair. S weeping, twisting away from his touch, not looking at him

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: They're not gonna burn us, okay? I swear. Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: They are. They are. Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he whispers in her ear, desperate:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie. I sometimes feel like I've forgotten something important. Something I was supposed to hold onto really tight...but I lost it, without thinking, like a kid loses something, and I forgot I ever even had it to start with...

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: That's stupid. You're stupid, you're not making sense.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You remember where we met, Millie? How long ago? Do you remember what I said? Do you remember what you said? What you were wearing? Or have the pills taken all that away? Can you remember?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Course I remember. Stupid jerk.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: No. Go away. Montag eases off, seeing the truth. She doesn't remember. takes the book gently from her hand and sits up, his back against the hallway wall.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yesterday, I saw a woman burn herself, and I thought, my God. What's in these books that could make a person do that? Is it because she's crazy? Or because she isn't? I deserve to know that. {looks to her) I love you, Millie. And I want you to help me. If the book says nothing, we'll burn it together. Okay? Millie also sits up, her back against the opposite wall. facing profiles.) He opens the book, starts to read:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: "Chapter one. The Sound of the Shell. (beat) The boy with the fair hair lowered himself down the last few feet of rock and began to pick his way toward the lagoon. Though he had taken off his school sweater and trailed it now from one hand..." CAMERA CLOSES IN TIGHTER AND TIGHTER on Millie in profile Montag's voice drones on, her head bowed, tears slipping her nose. She's trembling, trying to hold very still.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: ",,.when a bird, a vision of red and yellow, flashed upwards with a witch-like cry; and this cry was echoed by another..." Millie rises abruptly from frame, goes down the hallway p Montag, vanishes into the TV room, slams the door. HOLD ON Montag. Listening. The TV goes on, turned way up Montag sags, the breath draining from his body, the life seeming to go out of him as:

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK, (SLO-MO)
dialogues.text: slips from his hand, tumbling toward the floor...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -..and the book lands before us, normal speed, whacking a table top. ANGLE UP TO: Beatty, seated in a poker game, surrounded by firemen. He looks up from the book to:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I found this in the Scooper.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PILOT FLAMES BLOOM with a gentle hiss. The door opens, revealing Beatty and Montag, faces awash in the glow. Mon lays "Lord of the Flies" inside, cranks the jets. An ERUP OF FLAME leaps up, engulfing the screen...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-and FLAMES engulf the screen, transitioning from fire fire on the dissolve, roiling in SLO-MO. The fire sweeps revealing Montag and his flame thrower, finger on the tri face caked with soot. ANGLE WIDENS as he moves through a surreal, flaming lands igniting piles of books, laundry on lines, makeshift tent Other firemen are revealed as we WIDEN, also burning. Jet fire streak across frame. FIREBALLS billow into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOMELESS
dialogues.text: are leaving with what they can carry, lines of ragged peo being walked through checkpoints. Some Mechanical Hounds there, sniffing them all to make sure no books get throug

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: pauses. At his feet are piles of debris -- a child's arml doll, a dented metal teapot. He kicks some crap aside, an Books. Hidden hastily beneath. Just part of the garbage. Montag glances around. Nobody can see him out here in all confusion and smoke. He grabs the books, stuffs them insi his coat. Gone like a magic trick, poof, just like that. moves on, laying down a blast of FLAME as he goes...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -.-and we find him in the bathroom, reading late into the night, a few books at his feet...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and he comes up a corridor, shouting instructions as w are ripped out. And as he turns the corner he performs an magic trick, scooping books from the torn-out walls and m them disappear. He keeps moving, nerves steady -- as with life of crime, once begun, it gets easier every time... cur TO: INT - BATHROOM - NIGHT. +--and the books grow in number as the hours grow late...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A search-line of FIREMEN led by Montag crosses a weedy ya past crumbling stone statues and mute tile fountains, swe the ground with IMAGING DETECTORS. The screens begin FLAS Montag turns, hollers, motioning for the Scooper...

dialogues.speaker: TIMECUT
dialogues.text: .--which rips up a huge mound of dirt and backs away, the falling dirt revealing packets of books wrapped in heavy plastic, buried here for countless decades... Montag hollers for the pumpers and men scurry off. As the go, he comes forward, crouches to the dirt... .-and digs out a single book, ancient and ornate, wrapped heavy plastic sheet...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-which he carefully slices with a razor, peeling it awa reveal a beautiful Bible, stunningly old and rare...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: --.and Montag pokes up through a small trapdoor, lays dow the Bible...as ANGLE PULLS BACK to reveal the crawlspace with stacks of books, dozens of them...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: .-.and BLASTS OF FLAME are unleashed and unleashed again, sailing up corridors, up staircases, though rooms; explod writhing, funneling, roaring...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ...and again we find Montag reading. The bathroom has bec his late night refuge. CAMERA CLOSES IN on his face... ---and we hear a SOFT KNOCK. His gaze snaps up.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Something outside. I'm scared.
Montag wraps his book in a towel, slips it under the sink rises to the door and opens it a crack, revealing:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: First I thought I was dreaming. It was outside the window, moving around in the flower bed. Then I heard it scratching at the door. I think it was some kind of animal. Like a dog. Montag joins her in the hallway and holds still, listenin Is that a sound out there? A trash can lid? The wind? He moves through the dark house to the living room, Milli lagging fearfully behind. He goes to the window, eases his fingers through the blin opens them a crack. There, outside in the moonlight:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (whispers) It's a Hound. Millie's breath catches.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: They're coming for us. They're gonna burn us.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. It's moving off. (beat) We send them out sometimes on slow nights. Check out the neighborhoods. Let them sniff around. It's random. She stares at him, not convinced. She turns without a further word, disappears to the bedro Montag peers out again, perhaps not so convinced himself.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag wakes to darkness, Millie beside him. He lies for long moment, staring at nothing, wondering what woke him. He becomes aware of a RISING ORANGE GLOW in the room. He up, the glow intensifying on his face. He jumps out of be rushes to the window... ..-wWhere leaping flames are reflected in the glass.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Montag running barefoot in his pajama bott coming up the sidewalk, elbowing through knots of spectat passing a firetruck... He stops, and CAMERA COMES AROUND TO REVEAL: Clarisse's house in flames. Fireballs rising. Men on the with flamethrowers. He hears a YOWL and looks down as an orange cat streaks b disappearing through the legs of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PIREMAN
dialogues.text: Sir, please move back to the barricades!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (flashes his ID tags) Montag. District four. I live a few houses down.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (looks over) Some neighbors you had. Just never know, I guess. He's idly paging a book in his hands. Montag glances down and, with a jolt, realizes it's "Charlie the Choo Choo." The captain moves off, tosses it onto a roaring pyre of o books.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Are they in custody?

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: Drove off five minutes before we got here. Probably saw the Hound sniffing the neighborhood. Don't worry, cops'll get 'em. He moves off. Montag is left staring at the flames.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag watches as Millie lays breakfast on the table. The tension between them is thick. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Get rid of the books. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag stands staring at Clarisse's house, collar turned against the chill. It's quiet now, not a soul in sight. L of the house remains. Charred timbers and ashes. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Arriving for work, Montag gets waved into Beatty's office

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I was skimming the city reports from last night. (nods to his computer) Had some excitement out your way? Just a few doors down, was it? (Montag nods) Rang up Jeffers at third district. He said you showed up barefoot in pajamas. Ready to pitch in and lend a hand, were you?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Always, Captain. You know that. Beatty, affable, turns his screen so Montag can see it. T plasma image shows the faces of Clarisse's family. Father Mother. Cousins. Beatty taps down, idly scanning...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: This file goes back generations. A long line of misfits and oddballs. They were even homeschooling the daughter, you imagine? Stunning, the crap they got away with, wearing the masks of normal people. (beat) Ever meet them? A loaded question, posed casually. Montag knows it, too. keeps his tone conversational:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Waved to the man over the fence once. And the little girl... Clarisse's face appears on screen.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: ---that's the one. Said hello to me one night. She was odd. (off Beatty's look) Said there was a man in the moon.
Beatty blinks and laughs, nonplussed. Montag exits...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -.+.and we find him later at a desk amid the quiet activi the firehouse, studying the same report that Beatty had p up earlier. Checking out Clarisse's family. He pauses as: A new face comes up. The name: "David Faber." Uncle. The photo's a mugshot. The man's got quite a rapsheet. Mo ‘scans down the list of arrests, words flashing onscreen: Antisocial. Unpatriotic. Agitator. Anarchist. Political undesirable. Worst of all: "Convicted of harboring books.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Current whereabouts? The computer responds instantly with an address.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: DAVID FABER ventures out into an dismal, overcast day. He turns up his overcoat collar and crosses the street. ANGLE SHIFTS TO Montag. He steps off the curb to follow. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Faber's alone at a chess table, the top faded and old, pl solo. Every so often he tosses some crumbs to the birds. He becomes aware of Montag some distance away. Faber give him a glance or two, tries to ignore him. Montag comes this way. Faber tosses the last of the crumb sweeps his chess pieces into a bag, gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Mr. Faber? Wait.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: (quickens his pace) I haven't done anything. I'm trying to live my life. Please leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you!

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Talk to my probation officer, I a report to him every other day.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Please--slow down!

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) Look, Mr. Fireman, sir -- I did my time, okay? (shows his barcode number _ tattoo) Five years in the re-education camp. I've paid my debt to society. So... He keeps going, Montag dogging him:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You're Clarisse's uncle.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: I'm her father's uncle. What's it to you? What do you know about Clarisse?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We were friends. She talked about ~ you.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: She told me you got arrested once for being a pedestrian.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Proves nothing. Says so in my file.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: And you told her that firemen used to put out fires a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: They did. Still proves nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Faber, I-- Faber whirls on him, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: It's not enough you people burned them out and set them on the run? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FABER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're gone and I have no idea where! Same as I told those other men last night, the ones with the warrants! And now you know! So, please, just let me go my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faber hurries off, leaving Montag standing there...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-but Montag's not giving up. He enters the building. It overcrowded and squalid. KIDS are yelling in the hallways laundry is strung from the landings. He passes loud music, loud Tvs, loud arguments spilling f various apartments. Some people notice him, a few doors s He goes past a young, tired-looking WHORE in her doorway, robe hanging open, smoking and checking him out.

dialogues.speaker: WHORE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, looking for company? (calls after him) I love firemen! Do you right! Montag comes to the stairs and finds a MAN sitting in a c with a shotgun across his knees -- the building's day gua Montag shows him his Fire Department I.D.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Faber?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Faber's in his strappy t-shirt, riding a stationary bicyc It's not a workout -- the bike's connected by electrical to a series of old car batteries that Faber is charging. A KNOCK at the door. Faber gets off the bike, breathing h toweling sweat from his face.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We met in the park.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Veys mir. Look, I told you, unless you have a warrant--

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faber sighs, opens the door, peers out.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Show me. Montag raises his gym bag into view.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Looks heavy. For a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: dust give me a few minutes, okay? Please. This visit's unofficial.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Do I have a choice, I asked? I'm guessing not, I answered. Okay, Mr. Pest. You intrigue me. (swings the door open) Enter freely and of your own will. Montag enters. Faber crosses to the sink:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Pardon my sweat. Close to dinner time. I was charging the batteries for the stove. (grabs a glass) ww I offer you something? An aperitif? A glass of slime from the tap?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No thanks. Faber pours himself some water.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Well then. Formalities are done. Who are you, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'm Montag. Your nephew's family lived on my street.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Oh, you're that fireman, the one down the street. Ah. You turned in the alarm, of course.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: No. I told you, Clarisse was my friend. Faber goes to the table, sits. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag moves 74.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: And so you'd like to know where they are, check up on her, see she's safe. And I'm supposed to fall for that. I have to say, you guys used to be more clever than this.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I don't want to know where they are. I just...if you ever get the chance, please let her know how sorry I am and that it wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: That's all? (Montag nods) I won't get the chance. But your sentiment is duly noted. We done? to the table, lays his gym bag before Faber.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: A loaf of bread? A jug of wine? Dirty gym clothes? I give up. Montag unzips the bag, pulls out something thick and heav Paber's eyes widen as he realizes what it is -- the ancient, ornate Bible Montag dug out of the ground. For a long mom the man forgets to breathe, deeply stunned.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: And this is?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: For you.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: For me. I see. (clears his throat) The Revised Testament, government approved version, is one of the few books not on the burning list. This, however, appears to be New Testament, done by hand prior to the invention of the printing press. It's very old and beyond rare, which means the Pope himself would gladly light the match. I'm sorry, but I can't accept your gift, seeing as how very illegal it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag starts pulling more books from his bag, stacking t on the table. Faber's eyes start to glaze.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I can't keep any of it. I was hoping you could find a home for them.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Too bad one of them isn't a dictionary, we could look up the word "entrapment." Along with the word "sucker." {off Montag's look) How stupid do I look? You're trying to get me burned out! Not to mention sent back for re-education, only this time for life! Having been there, I'm compelled to say no. But don't think I didn't appreciate the attempt. It was very amusing. (rises, shooing him) Gather your things and go. Out, out, out. Thanks for the laugh. Montag stands up, thinks a moment. He then stuns Faber by opening the Bible and ripping out the first page.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Montag pulls a lighter from his pocket, clicks it. A tiny of BLUE FLAME leaps up. He holds up the page and ignites The page curls and burns before Faber's eyes. He watches ashes swirl toward the ceiling as: Montag rips the second page out, holds it up. Faber's agh

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What --are--you--doing? Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (mutters) You and my wife. Montag applies the flame. The second page burns. More ash swirl. He reaches for the third page...

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: No, no, wait--

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I told you I can't keep it. That leaves us two choices--

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: --us, us? How'd this turn into us--

dialogues.speaker: . MONTAG
dialogues.text: --you take the books, or I do my job. This is what I do. Watch. And he rips the third page out, raises it, brings the lig close. The page starts to blacken and burn.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Up it goes. Faber stifles a scream. He lunges and grabs the page, sla it to the table, smothering it.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, stop! Just stop it! He snatches up the Bible and backs away, clutching it to chest. Pause. Faber

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Idiot! Sadist! This could be the last Christian Bible in this hemisphere!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Are you Christian?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: I'ma Jew!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Then what do you care?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: I care, I care! It's us, it's who we are, it's who we were! (off Montag's look) That's why this world sucks, kiddo! We don't know who to be. anymore, because we don't know where we came from or how we got here, or the mistakes we made along the way! It's all been erased and we've forgotten how to even ask the damn questions! All we know is what they tell us, that parade of shitwits on TV, that's become our excuse for truth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks down at the Bible in his hands. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Look at these pages. How many believers spent their lives going blind in some dark abbey copying them by hand...so you can burn them in seconds?
He can't resist -- he raises it to his nose, inhales.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: God. I can smell the centuries. (beat) Go ahead. Call in your alarm. I'm not giving this back. Montag meets Faber's defiant gaze. He's seen that look on before, in the eyes of an old woman holding a kitchen mat

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I have more books at home. A few dozen in my attic. I'll bring them to you the next few days. Unless you decide to turn me in, of course. Guess I'll just have to trust you. Faber stares at him, stunned, as we

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The roof is a jumble of electricity-generating windmills spinning on the breeze, plus a maze of chicken and rabbit coops. The view is spectacular in the gathering twilight, traffic whizzing, the last traces of sunset filtering ama colors through the poisoned air.

dialogues.speaker: FABER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's a book? Just a person who lived, that's all. Somebody who wanted to tell you something and cared enough to write it down. BOOMING DOWN, we find Faber and Montag seated on a low st wall separating one level of the roof from another. Faber got one of Montag's books in his hands, turning the pages

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Good books, bad books...they're just voices asking to be heard. They're us.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: My wife says books aren't real.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: She's right, thank God! You can shut 'em up, you can close 'em, you can say "hold on a moment!" They piss you off, you can even throw ‘em across the room. But in all my years I have never been able to (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FABER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: reason with a TV set. Ever try to argue with a four-wall plasma screen room with a zillion channels and surround sound? Can't be done! All you can do is submit! {to the sky) I surrender! Tell me what kind of toilet paper to use, I'll do it! Montag iaughs. Faber rises, agitated: FABER . You can laugh, kiddo, but there's your truth. From the Jesuit priest who burned the great Mayan library so the natives would only have Jesus to think about, to the invading armies who burned the Library at Alexandria three times -- three times -- there's always some schmuck who wants to take away your right to think for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: History begins with me?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: My God, a quote yet. Yes, O Learned Sage, history begins with me. (hefts the book) And don't bother showing up with your own ideas, just take the ones we give you. Or we'll accuse you of treason. Heresy. Burn you. Bury you in mass graves. Kick your ass. Faber draws closer, hands the book to Montag.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: It's not even about books. It's about control. The people who run things keeping themselves in power by making sure nobody knows enough to ask uncomfortable questions. Keep the TVs going and the trivia flowing! Who's dating who, who's wearing what, will the pop star get married, will she get divorced, what's happening on "The Family" this week? A river of meaningless shit flooding our brains twenty four hours a day until we've got no brains left! That's power, kiddo. On a mass scale. Intractable, entrenched, unassailable. And, I'm sorry to say, it sums up the lie your life has been.
Faber's suddenly feeling shaky. He turns, gazing out over city, trying to steady himself.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: You kidding me? I'm terrified. Lightheaded. I can't believe I'm even talking to you. (feels his own forehead) I didn't have enough trouble. Mr. Lunatic shows up. Idiot me, I open the door and say come in. What do you want, Mr. Lunatic? Speak!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (rises) I thought we could help each other.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: (laughs) Don't bullshit yourself, kiddo. It's unseemly. You're a book-burner who woke up one day and realized you aren't quite the mindless robot they told you to be. You've fallen from grace, you poor sap, and now you ~ want absolution. All those heretics you've burned at the stake. Whitman. Thoreau. Dickens. Well, I don't do absolution. Try the Catholics. (heads for the coops) Anyway, you're a little late. Where were you twenty, thirty years ago? Back when I had piss and vinegar to spare?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Maybe you still do.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: That was then. I've since had my ass handed to me once or twice. All I wanna do now is sleep through the night.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE COOP MAZE
dialogues.text: Faber comes down the tunnel of cages, unlocks one. THREE CHICKENS squawk as he gathers eggs into a kitchen towel.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Charlotte. Emily. Anne. Thank you, my darlings. Another night I don't starve because of you.
Montag appears on the other side, peering through the mes Faber moves down the row to another cage.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Everybody knows there's a resistance Movement. You were a part of it. I'm not saying you still are. I'm just saying maybe you know. somebody who knows somebody.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Why? What do you think the resistance is, some well-oiled army ready to rise up and smite the wicked? It's little old ladies and people like me, hiding books in the shadows and shitting a brick every time the doorbell rings. Faber emerges from the tunnel of cages, rejoins Montag.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: That's all it's ever been. We're like those monks in the Dark Ages, hiding books so the kings and popes can't burn 'em. Hoping someday knowledge might be welcome again.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I can get you those books.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Is that what this is about? A formation of high-level BOMBERS go streaking across the sky, tearing the stratosphere with sound. Faber looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: See the news this morning? We started using nukes. Pakistan's glowing. Genie's out of the bottle again, kiddo. Think we'll survive the summer? Me, I wouldn't bet on getting through the week. And you're worried about books. A look passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You've been pissed off all your life, old man. You gonna quit now? Paber weighs this madness, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Dank and musty, lit by a single bare bulb. Faber's putter in semi-darkness, going through various drawers and toolb fingers rooting piles of screws, nails, parts. He finds what he's looking for, holds it to the light, bl dust off -- it's a "seashell," a tiny earplug/transmitter

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: You think I'm old. Hope this thing still works. (hands it to Montag) Stick it in your ear. Montag slips it into his left ear, finds a comfortable fi Faber pulls out a transmitter the size of a pack of cigar and a corresponding headset. He clips the transmitter to belt, plugs in the headset, puts it on. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Hear me?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (startled) Yeah. In my head.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: And I can hear you. They built 'em good back then. Now listen, no more showing up at my door. From now on we're never seen together and we never talk on the phone. We stay in touch only with this... (taps his headset) .-.like two tin cans and a string.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Understood.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: (beat) Good luck, Mr. Fireman. Try not to get me burned. cut To:

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: STEADICAM brings Montag into the firehouse, past men poli the truck, past others performing maintenance duties, pas the brass poles, past the Hound. It all looks surreal to him. He's seeing it with differen eyes now. He steps to the timeclock, hand on the scanner

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Montag. Clocking in. ...and as he turns, ANGLE SHIFTS TO REVEAL: Beatty standing there. Blocking his way. Smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: You're late. Before Montag can utter a word: WHONK!WHONK!WHONK! The fi alarm. Deafening.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Well, nevermind, just in time! Thank goodness, it's just not a fire without you! (turns, yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firemen running, boots all a-scuffle, grabbing HELMETS of pegs, yanking equipment from storage lockers, cascading d brass poles, swarming the Salamander, strapping in...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...and emerging into the night, firetruck and control van HORNS BLARING AND LIGHTS FLASHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dizzy blur of motion and lights. Beatty looks back, che the faces of his men.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Montag, where's that grin?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: The fierce grin of all men singed and driven back by flame! Isn't this what we love? Isn't this what we do best?

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A HOVERCOPTER is circling as the Salamander comes rumblin the street. The firetruck stops. CAMERA CLOSES IN as the firemen unbuckle, some of them ju down, others pausing uncertainly...

dialogues.speaker: CARILLO
dialogues.text: Sir? Is this our jurisdiction?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: No worries. I've cleared it through channels. ...and Beatty glances back as CAMERA CONTINUES PAST HIM, closing on Montag. He's at a loss, trying to comprehend:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We...we've stopped in front of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag's house sits on its quiet street. The firemen star assemble a bit awkwardly, not sure what's going on, but:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: At ease. We're dispensing with protocol. Tonight is a special occasion. Tonight we do things just a little differently. (glances up to Montag) Isn't that right? Feeling like a man in a dream, Montag steps down and walk forward to face Beatty.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (announcing to all) No pumpers! No kerosene! No pretty beacon on the lawn! Tonight we get a special treat! A display of dedication and skill nonpareil! One man! One flamethrower! (locks eyes with Montag) Mr. Ormsby! Mr. Landers! Bring one down, if you please! Ormsby and Landers heft a flamethrower off its mount and it down from the truck, hustling it over as: The front door of the house bursts open and Millie hurrie down the walk, dressed for travel and dragging a suitcase

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: She turned in the alarm?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Don't blame her, Montag, not for your stupidity. Montag, stunned, meets her as she reaches the curb. She's exried out, looking back at the house:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Everything gone now, everything. Poor house. Poor family. All gone. Montag steps close, desperate, hoping for some glimmer of tenderness or redemption.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Millie. I love you. She looks him in the eye and:

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: (softly) I hope you die. She brushes past him as Beatty remands her to the TWO COP the scene:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Officers. A domestic dispute. Would you please see after Mrs. Montag? Take her where she wants to go? As Millie is helped away, Beatty snaps his fingers at Orm and Landers. They sling the flamethrower onto Montag's ba tightening straps and snapping buckles as:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Don't look so shocked. You didn't leave her much choice, did you? Poor thing was terrified. It was the third alarm she called in. I ignored the first two, told her to be patient. Said you'd come around. What a sad disappointment you are. How are those straps, secure? Let's get that pilot lit. Montag activates the gas feed. Beatty himself applies the igniter. A gentle flame blooms.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Now. Let's finish what you started. They march toward the house, Beatty and Montag, as the ot watch. Beatty turns back, calling to them... .

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Break out some windows! Let's get some cross ventilation! --and in that moment, Montag sneaks the "seashell" from h pocket and slips it in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Faber reacts as his transmitter activates with a small re light and a BRIEF TONE. He grabs the unit, slips on the h with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What's on your mind, kiddo?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag, of course, can't reply. He enters the house with Beatty, gazing around to find that Millie's taken the boo from the attic and strewn them all over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: FABER'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Hello? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I can't believe this is happening to me.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Funny how that works. Everybody thinks, everybody is absolutely certain, that nothing will ever happen to them. Others die, I go on. Others get caught, not me. Consequences? Never. Except sometimes there are. And by the time they catch up, it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON Faber, heart sinking as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Montag. I'm listening. I don't know what's happening, but I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WINDOWS START BREAKING from outside, glass exploding acro floors. CAMERA CLOSES IN TIGHTER AND TIGHTER ON MONTAG as

dialogues.speaker: . CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: You're a well read man, how about a few well-chosen quotes? No? Allow me. "Day of wrath, O day of mourning! See fulfilled the prophet's warning! Heaven and earth in ashes burning!" (bellows)
Montag hits the trigger and FIRES A BLAST OF FLAME into t living room, igniting the furniture. WHOOOOOOSH!

dialogues.speaker: AGAIN
dialogues.text: WHOOOOOOSH! The living room walls now catch, sending up s of fire. Books on the floor ignite.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: That's the ticket, well done! You can't tell me that didn't feel good! All your sins washed away with good cleansing fire! Onward, Montag! Lead the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag leads Beatty down the hallway into:

dialogues.speaker: THE TV ROOM
dialogues.text: It's on, of course. "The Family" is playing.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Something here you'd like to burn? The sorrow of past regrets? The stench of failure? That blow-dried imbecile and his chattering hag? Montag pulls the trigger. The FIRE BURSTS FORTH, hitting screens and imploding them. The vacuum sucks fire in and belches it out again, plastic igniting as the babble of t Family gives way to the HIDEOUS SHRIEK OF MELTING SPEAKER THE BEDROOM: Montag stares at the bed he shared for years with his wife. WHOOOQOOSH! Up it goes, a funeral pyre... THE KITCHEN: WHOOOOOSH! Table, countertop, appliances -- THE HALLWAY: A flaming corridor. Beatty and Montag retrea the front door, Montag laying down BLASTS OF FLAME...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -..and they emerge coughing, dark with soot, as the house behind them burns. They turn to watch.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: (gentle) Bad dream's over. Fire and smoke.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Montag? Can you run? Can you try to get away?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: There's no running away from this.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL VAN
dialogues.text: The Controllers are watching their monitors. Suddenly, FL LINES appear on screen, BEEPING, searching...

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: I've got a signal. Some kind of bandwidth.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Source? -+-and the crosshairs converge on Montag.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch is transmitting.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: How long have you known?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: From the start. Montag, you idiot. Our Hound smelled the books on you. He raises his plasma screen clipboard, punches in a playb command, turns it so Montag can see. On it, a recording: THE HOUND'S POV: We've seen this moment before -- Montag around the firetruck the night he took the first two book freezing in his tracks as he encounters the beast.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: {enters new command) So I checked the surveillance cams. Lo and behold. A new image pops up. From a hidden ceiling cam, we see Mo pulling the first book out of the Scooper blade. Beatty f the image, tracking it in for a TIGHT CLOSEUP.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: "Charlie the Choo Choo?" You threw it all away -- your career, your marriage, your life -- for goddamn "Charlie the Choo Choo?"
Controller #2 hurries up from the control van, pulls Beat aside, whispers in his ear. Beatty gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Really? The man nods. Beatty sends him off, turns back to Montag. There's a new look in Beatty's eye -- hungry, vengeful.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I gave you every chance. Tried to woo you, reason with you. I even sent the Hound to sniff around your house at night and throw a scare into you. Even that didn't work... (cocks his head) -.-though it did get your neighbors burned out and on the run. Yes, your fault. All your fault. (closing on him) You dense...arrogant...traitorous... ungrateful little bastard. Beatty stuns Montag by hauling off and slapping him hard the ear (the one with the seashell in it). WHAP!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -- and the sound makes Faber jump, wrenching off his head as if he'd been slapped himself --

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: After all I did for you. After the kindness I showed. WHAP! Another slap across the same ear. Montag clutches t side of his head in agony --

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: I vouched for you. Put my professional standing on the line for you. This is how you repay me? And betray me? WHAP! Beatty slaps him a third time -- only this time use his other hand. The blow rocks Montag's head, and: The seashell flies from his ear, skittering onto the pave

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL VAN
dialogues.text: Controller #1 enters a command:

dialogues.speaker: CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Jamming transmission now.  89.

dialogues.speaker: BEATTY
dialogues.text: strolls to the seashell, scoops it off the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Your pal Faber? (off Montag's shock) Of course I know! I've been tracking your every step! There are cameras on every street corner of this city, you moron! And Faber's been under surveillance from the moment his nephew went on the run! (raises his clipboard) We have you talking to him in the park! Entering his building! Chatting on the roof! Want to see? Or are you willing to take my word for it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Faber! Run!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Go ahead, yell. He can't hear you. We've jammed the transmission. (closing in) The next thing Mr. Faber knows, the police will be kicking his door in. WS Want to go over there, just to see the look on his face? Oh, dear, I almost forgot. You'll be in custody yourself. For treason and sedition. (stops before him) If you're through making a fool of yourself, you're under arrest. Beat. Montag stands pinned in Beatty's gaze. And then: CLICK. He works the safety catch on the flamethrower. The flame billows up with a gentle hiss. Beatty goes stiff, eyes widening slightly. And he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Well, that's one way to get an audience. Hold a gun on a man and make him listen to your speech. Well, speech away. What'll it be this time? Why don't you belch Shakespeare at me? "There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, for I am armed so strong in honesty that they pass me as an idle wind, which I respect not!" How's that? Go ahead, you trembling little prick. Pull the trigger.
Montag is trembling. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: We never burned right.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BEATTY
dialogues.text: Hand it over, Montag. You're done. Beat . WHOOOOOOOOSH! An ERUPTION OF FIRE leaps out and hits Beat square in the chest, a searing fist of flame that grips h envelops him, drives him back, blows him off his feet. Beatty sails through the air on a booster of fire, a blaz shrieking scarecrow. He lands on his back in a flaming he arms flailing and legs drumming...and then goes still. A hush falls. For an extended moment the scene is a table everybody frozen, faces slack with unspeakable shock. IN THE CONTROL VAN _ t., They can't believe what they just saw on their screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Circling the scene below, monitors recording everything.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: stands with the murder weapon in his hands, just as stunn as everybody else. He's looking at his hands as if they'd acted on their own volition, as if they weren't even his. He looks up. Firemen are backing away, a few turn and run Montag knows there's no going back. Ever. He embraces his moment of insanity, sets his feet --

dialogues.speaker: RUUUUUN
dialogues.text: -- and begins to burn. WHOOOOOSH! Firemen scatter, runnin clear as an ARC OF FLAME sweeps up and down the Salamande engulfing the firetruck, turning it into a blazing pyre. Montag turns, swiveling the nozzle toward the control van ++-and WHOOOOOOSH! FLAMES envelop the forward half of the van. The controllers scatter from their posts and evacuat out the back doors, running into the night as: Montag circles around, BLASTING FIRE into the now empty v Monitor screens EXPLODE, spewing glass.

He turns again, SCREAMING now, primal, stripped bare, hos the firetruck again, burning everything, burning all. The flamethrowers lining the truck start EXPLODING on the mounts, one after another, sending FIREBALLS into the sky The hovercopter veers off, fleeing the explosions. BOOOOM! The fuel tank blows, lifting the Salamander into air and slamming it awesomely back down again, now a tang of shattered, flaming wreckage. And then all is still. Montag stands, alone now, the stre around him in flames. In a daze, he walks over to his murdered captain. The bod still burning. Montag scans the pavement, finds: The seashell. It's a bit scorched, but seems intact. He p it up, holds it to his ear with a shaky hand. He hears ST intermittent sound -- a voice?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Faber? Faber? Can you hear me? The Mechanical Hound lunges from the flaming wreckage of firetruck, trailing fire as it streaks across the pavemen WHAM! The beast hits Montag like a train, taking him off feet. He hits the pavement hard, the seashell goes flying The Hound starts savaging him, Montag bashing it with the flamethrower nozzle, trying to drive it off. The beast clamps down on his thigh and the hypo tongue sh out, jabbing hard into Montag's flesh. Montag SCREAMS as plunger depresses and the amber fluid starts to flow. But only half the dose is emptied, because Montag rams the flamethrower nozzle into the Hound's mouth and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOOOM! A BLAST OF FLAME erupts, driving the beast back, blowing it off its feet. Flaming fluid spatters everywher Montag's on fire, rolling across the pavement, trying to smother the flames. He yanks the small extinguisher off h arm and hoses himself with retardant, putting himself out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up, sees the flaming Hound coming for him again. lets the thing have it in the face with ANOTHER BLAST OF driving it back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and the flames damage the Hound's optics, its image of world jittering to snow as FLASHING WORDS appear: "Warnin Optic Damage. Warning. Optic damage."

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: watches the Hound spinning in circles, burning and blinde enraged, lashing out in all directions. Montag rolls over, tries to get to his feet. He collapses SCREAMING, his leg useless from the dose of procaine. He throws the quick-release buckles and shrugs the flamet off. Trying again, he manages to get halfway to his feet, hobbling across the pavement to the seashell. He scoops i up, jams it in his ear, fleeing the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Faber! Run! Get out! They'll be there any minute!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Faber's frantic, tweaking the signal, trying to hear.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: You there? You hear me? Montag?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (£iltered) --et out--r-partment--ow abou--you-- ere--ny minu--et ou--now--

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: On the run, hobbling:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: It all went wrong! You have to get out, understand? They're coming for you! You have to run!

dialogues.speaker: FABER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) --nderstand--ndersta--t--hear you-- are you--abou--you--pla--at-- Static. Montag crashes through a backyard, through the la line, over a low fence. Dogs start BARKING. Lights come o CAMERA FOLLOWS as he keeps going, getting dopey, the proc hitting his brain. He's crossing an open field, some bush and trees. He shakes his head, trying to clear it... ...and stops, the world swimming before his eyes. He's se double, triple. He crawls into some bushes and collapses rolling onto his back, staring at the sky. SIRENS are wailing somewhere. Hovercopter SEARCHLIGHTS pr in the distance. Suddenly, the signal clears:

dialogues.speaker: FABER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) --ntag? Montag?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yes? Yes? I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN MONTAG'S AND FABER'S LOCATIONS
dialogues.text: Faber's in his overcoat, racing down the back stairs of h building, careening from landing to landing:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: I'm leaving. I'm getting out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: {processes that) Good. That's good.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Can you tell me where you are?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Um...not so good. Not so good right now. Where? Um. No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: You don't know where you are? Are you hurt? Can you walk? Faber dashes out the back door and into the street, getti lost among the pedestrians. He glances back. POLICE CARS pulling up at his building b.g. He missed them by moments

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Montag? Montag? Montag's lying there, staring at the sky. He starts to la

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: It's there. I see it.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Clarisse said so. It's there. There is a man in the moon... (laughs) +-.or. Could be drugs.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Montag! You have to think clearly! Focus!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Um, okay. Focusing. Right.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: There's an abandoned district east of downtown. Across the river from the power plant. You know it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Power plant? Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Across the river from the plant! Old round building, 10th and Savoy! If I can't come to you, kiddo, you gotta come to me! C'mon, you can do this! 10th and Savoy! Montag sits up painfully, trying to clear his head.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, 10th and Savoy. Shut up already. Montag takes a final, longing look at the moon...and with every ounce of willpower he's got, pushes to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-while Faber clicks off his transmitter, comes around t corner -- and stops, gazing up in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reveals a GIANT STREET MONITOR on a building. On it, five stories high, is the footage of Montag killing Beatty tak from the hovercopter. CROWDS are gathering to watch as th show the event again and again, along with all the lurid, late-breaking details. Faber looks around. Every monitor in the city's showing i

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Rubble everywhere, like the surface of the moon. The city looms before us. Montag enters frame, limping toward it..

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-while far behind him, twigs are snapping. Something co through the bushes, emerges into the moonlight:

The Hound. Scorched and semi-blind, eyes stuttering. It's limping, gears and servos grinding with every step. But t damn thing still works -- especially its nose. It sniffs spot where Montag was sprawled, presses on...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Deserted streets. Montag limps along a brick wall upon wh a long scrawl of graffiti is spray-painted. He comes around a corner, gazes up. There, looming above is the ROUND BUILDING at 10th and Savoy -- a ten-story cy of brick, grimy as hell, ringed with windows and fire esc hemmed in by other buildings just as ancient and decrepit

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Montag enters through a broken doorway. The place is tras Rats squeak and scurry. He works his way through darkness

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (softly) Faber? ..-and_a DARK SHAPE lunges from the shadows. It's a HOMELESS MAN -- huge, bearded, malevolent. He's go iron pipe in hands, poised to attack.

dialogues.speaker: HUGE HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: You the fireman? Montag nods cautiously...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-.and is led into the rotunda. GROUPS OF HOMELESS are h in the shadows around small cookfires, glaring suspicious The huge homeless man taps him, directs his attention up. CAMERA ANGLES UP to reveal that the interior of the build is open all the way to the ceiling ten floors above -- ea floor is a round landing encircling the open shaft up the middle. A face appears high above, peering down -- Faber.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The Hound sniffs along the same graffitied wall. It pause the corner, looks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .;:and the image of the round building flashes and stutte flashes and stutters...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-While a BEEPING SIGNAL FLASHES on a screen over a SATE VIEW of the city. A POLICE DISPATCHER is intently monitor the signal as his CAPTAIN leans into frame.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: Been tracking this for a few minutes now.. Signal's faint. In and out. It's Beatty's Hound.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Pinpoint it before you lose it. And I mean to the square yard. The dispatcher clicks the image down closer and closer... the round building is prominent in frame.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Faber helps Montag along the curved landing past long row tall sheet-covered shelves, the smoke from the cookfires drifting up from below. Montag's leaning on Faber, limpin Faber pulls him into a dark cubby hole between shelves. T area contains a cot, a few chairs, a sleeping bag, some t pots and pans are on a crate. Montag sits heavily on the

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: You gonna make it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: My head feels clearer. Leg hurts like hell.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: But can you travel? (off Montag's look) I caught your act on the news. Me and a few billion other people. You're more wanted than Dillinger.
Faber starts pulling clothes from an old foot locker, roo through them, tossing some to Montag.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Lose the uniform. These are old and disgusting, but you'll be less conspicuous.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (sniffs the clothes) Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Far away as possible. (off Montag's look) There are some people, south of the city, up in the mountains... Montag painfully starts peeling his uniform off.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What kind of people?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: People. The kind that ran out of luck. Like us.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: They live in the mountains?

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Better than prison or re-education camps. You'll like these folks, they've got books. Lots of books. (tosses more clothes) In case we get separated, follow the river out of the city. Always stick to the river. Got that? C'mon, get those clothes on...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: AERIAL VIEW of the building, a beautiful establishing sho As OUR ANGLE SLOWLY DESCENDS... ---a PLITTER enters frame, dropping almost quietly from t sky. Followed by another. And another. A string of flitte descending toward the roof like drifting seed pods. A flitter is a one-man flying exoskeleton with four ducte turbofans, two above and two below -- picture a flying su open at the front that you step into. Each one is piloted a_ SWAT TROOPER, armored and helmeted, face invisible beh gleaming black visor. (Each flitter also has a pair of automated GATLING GUNS mounted on the sides.)

The flitters touch down one after another, gentle as kiss instantly taking off again as each trooper jumps clear. The flitters now become pilotless drones that begin circl the building, onboard systems going fully automatic, comp and gyros humming. IMAGING SCANNERS activate, methodicall sweeping the building...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF
dialogues.text: +..as the troopers scurry across the roof, weapons at the ready, moving with scary precision and hand signals. They assemble, crouching in a circle formation, waiting...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: -.-aS8 SWAT APC VEHICLES encircle the building on the gro also sweeping with imaging scanners. TROOPS come pouring of the vehicles, down alleys, taking up positions...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..as the SCANNER IMAGES come through on the monitors:

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: (on headset) We have movement throughout the building, mostly first floor, but scattered throughout all levels. At least four dozen unfriendlies by my count. Check your handhelds...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The troopers on the roof check their plasma palm-screens schematic of the building appears. TINY GLOWING DOTS indi the people inside.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A flitter is drifting sideways, tracking movement inside. it comes near, its onboard plasma screen shows TWO HUMAN FIGURES IN HEAT REGISTER SHAPES moving along together...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-which are Montag and Faber hurrying down the long row sheet-covered shelves. Montag's new clothes are pretty sh but at least the coat is warm.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: What was this place?

dialogues.speaker: . FABER
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, it was a book depository once. In fact...
He indicates the covered shelves. With a look of disbelie Montag reaches up grabs a sheet, pulls it off. A whole ro eight-foot high shelves are revealed, lined with books.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PABER
dialogues.text: Been trickling in here for decades. Probably the biggest stash in North America. Montag continues down the line, stunned, pulling off more sheets, revealing more books. He looks around, sees the v levels lined with covered shelves. Books beyond counting.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Some people and I were trying to work out a plan once to get 'em out of the city. Never could figure out how to move so many books, though, not with all the surveillance. Then I got arrested, and nothing ever came of it. That was years ago. And here they sit. Faber glances over, sees a book, pulls it off the shelf - paperback of "David Copperfield."

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Oh, nice. Take this one. For the trip. One of my favorites. Montag slips the book into his pocket with a smile, pulls down the next sheet, revealing: The flitter is outside one of the huge windows just on th other side of the shelves, hovering there, peering in. Mo stunned, frozen. Faber can't see from his angle:

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: What? The gatling guns abruptly swivel up and lock into place. Montag lunges, slamming into Faber as: BRRRAAAAAAAAPPP! The window and the surrounding walls EXP inward in a hurricane of masonry and glass. Montag and Fa hit the floor, the bookshelves above their heads vaporizi in a cloud of paper and wood...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF
dialogues.text: ---while the troopers, still in their circle formation, F BOLTS straight down into the tarpaper at their feet.

They turn, running out to form a wider circle where they different bolts into the roof -- unlike the first, these rappelling bolts. They quick-snap steel cables leading fr their chest harnesses, getting ready...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: ...as silence falls. Montag and Faber look up from the fl ears ringing, stunned. Montag crawls a few feet, peers ar what's left of the book shelf. A huge section of exterior wall is gone. The flitter's ou there, scanning and hovering. Locking in. Montag grabs Faber, pulls him to his feet, runs. BRRRRAAAAAAAAAAPPP! BRRRRAAAAAAAAPPP! The flitter tracks sideways, the wall disintegrating to dust in the onslaugh Montag and Faber run along the landing, books and shelvin exploding and vaporizing down the line behind them, churn into clouds of confetti, erupting out over the railing, s down to the floors below --

dialogues.speaker: GROUND FLOOR
dialogues.text: ~- where doors EXPLODE off their hinges, people SCREAMING scattering as troopers swarm in, laser-sighted assault ri sweeping to and fro in the darkness. BURSTS OF GUNFIRE er

dialogues.speaker: SEVENTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: -- as Montag and Faber dive to the floor. The flitter's g guns sweep over their heads and past them, ripping on dow the row of bookshelves...

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: ...and the flitter pauses, ceasing fire, coming back agai scan for its target...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: ...as Montag and Faber hug the floor, thinking the flitte gone, deafened by the GUNFIRE ECHOING through the buildin from below. A frozen moment as their eyes meet:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FABER
dialogues.text: Don't. I haven't felt this good in years. (a harsh laugh) I'm scared shitless.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Come on! Let's find a way out! They lunge to their feet, start to run, but:

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: BRRRRAAAAAAAAAAPPPPPPP! The flitter's gunfire chews throu the bookshelves again, churning up a tornado of debris... ..-as Montag spins, grabbing Faber's hand... ..-and the gunfire hits Faber, blowing him off his feet, knocking him sideways in a hazy red mist, ripping him out Montag's grasp, propelling him through the railing... ...as Montag spins, jerked off balance, also crashing thr the railing... ...and Faber sails out over the seven story drop inside t building, floating now in a halo of debris... ..-.and Montag plummets, grabbing the collapsing railing vaults out over the drop... ...and Faber falls away from us, drifting away like a dre down and down through the concentric circles of the landi toward the ground floor far below...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SPEED
dialogues.text: as Montag jerks to a stop, holding on to the shattered ra above his head for dear life, legs kicking wildly above t same sickening drop that Faber just took. The railing is disintegrating in his grasp, lurching, tea loose. He looks down, sees the sixth floor landing below feet. He tries to swing himself in, kicking as his toes b scrape the edge of the railing below... ..-and the railing he's holding rips loose. Montag plumme but hooks the sixth floor railing with his arms as he falls, slamming to a hard stop, SCREAMING as a few ribs b He holds on, dazed with shock and pain, trying to find th strength to pull himself up and over, while:

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF
dialogues.text: The troopers tuck their heads and detonate the inner circ of bolts -- a RING OF SMALL EXPLOSIONS kicks up...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: .--tearing loose a 20-foot diameter circle of the roof wh drops awesomely into the building, plummeting past Montag

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF
dialogues.text: ...and the troopers rush from their positions, jumping th " the smoking hole...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: +,-,and dropping down in a controlled freefall on their h rigs, laser sights sweeping the air. Homeless people break cover on various landings, running their lives. The troopers OPEN FIRE as they plummet on th cables, nailing evacuees on the run, shooting at anything that moves. Montag hauls himself up and over the railing onto the six floor landing. He staggers to his feet and darts off behi the bookshelves into the shadows as the troopers drop int frame from above, their GUNFIRE chewing the area...

dialogues.speaker: HANDHELD
dialogues.text: Montag runs, a breathless plunge through madness, turning this way and that, hearing yells and screams, barely avoi the troopers pounding up the stairs and sweeping the buil FLASHES OF GUNFIRE stuttering and lighting up the shadows He comes to a window. His only way out. He grabs an old m chair, swings it, bashes out the window. CAMERA FOLLOWS H out onto a fire escape six floors above the ground... -.-and his nemesis the flitter descends into frame before him, gatling guns swiveling up and locking into place. Montag freezes, nowhere to go, knowing he's dead, and: WHIIITITIRRRRR! The gatling guns spin, out of ammo. Montag's stunned. Hearing VOICES behind him.
