A heartbeat decision, and: He jumps from the landing, slams into the flitter, arms w around one of the lower turbofan ducts, hanging on for de life as the flitter bobs and spins, off balance, gyros struggling as it goes twisting out of control, sailing ac the street toward the face of the building next door...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: -;-and CRASHING AWESOMELY in through a window, dragging M with it, a storm of glass, Montag bouncing free as the ma goes banging/cartwheeling off across the floor, plowing t a wall and vanishing, gyros screaming as it keeps trying

Montag rises, dazed and bleeding, looks out the demolishe window. Across the street in the round building, the batt still rages, GUNFIRE FLASHING and echoing within. He turns away, horrified. CAMERA FOLLOWS as he limps thro the shadows, looking for a way out...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...and bashes through a basement-level window. He crawls hugging the shadows as a hovercopter SEARCHLIGHT sweeps b He can still hear sporadic gunfire from the block over. Montag runs down the alley, vanishing into the night...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The dispatcher's listening on his headset as the reports in. He turns, causing shock in the room:

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: We lost him. All eyes go to a MAN IN A SUIT in the shadows. This is no cop, but a DHS OFFICIAL -- a man of scary power. He steps forward. We don't see his face clearly, but the monitors the room are reflected in his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: We're on a live feed. Half the world is watching. No way do we "lose" him. (checks his watch) He dies in ten minutes. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: More populated here, a Times Square feel. Montag limps al in the flow of PEDESTRIANS, trying not to be noticed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: SWAT APCs screech up, followed by a Fire Department CONTR VAN. MEN jump out, circle to the rear, open the doors. TH MECHANICAL HOUNDS bound out, racing off in a pack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and we're watching from a HOVERCOPTER as the Hounds st across the street below us.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (heavily filtered) Air Nine to Command. There go the Hounds. Tracking now.
The AERIAL VIEW TILTS, following the Hounds...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ...While Montag limps on. He sees a COP CAR cruising this way, ducks into a crowd watching storefront VIDSCREENS:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ..-authorities now predicting a swift conclusion to the manhunt. Citizens are urged to get involved. Watch for this man! Guy Montag! Traitor! Cold-blooded murderer! A PHOTO OF MONTAG pops up. RACK FOCUS to the real Montag the midst of the crowd. He moves uneasily among them, cap pulled low, as the vid screens keep blaring:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: (touches his earpiece) Going live now to Dow Phillips on the scene...Dow, what's happening there? A REPORTER pops up, broadcasting live via minicam:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Steve, this was the scene just moments ago at Civic Center... Montag turns to see NEW FOOTAGE POP UP: the three Hounds leaping from the van and racing off.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: And they're off! Three Hounds -- count 'em, three! -- have been brought in to deal with the situation! Now that's unprecedented, but then so is this crime, which has shaken this city to its foundations... Montag's heart goes into his throat. He keeps moving...

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUNDS
dialogues.text: race through the streets, ignoring traffic, scattering pedestrians...

dialogues.speaker: THE HOVERCOPTER
dialogues.text: blasts over the city, turbofans SHRIEKING...

dialogues.speaker: AIR
dialogues.text: of city streets whizzing below us. The Hounds veer off in new direction...

dialogues.speaker: PILOT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (heavily filtered) Changing direction. Heading west.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: of the hovercopter above us. TILT DOWN TO a SWAT APC spee through the streets with LIGHTS AND SIRENS...

dialogues.speaker: APC TROOPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (heavily filtered) Copy that. Heading west.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: +++a8 STREETCORNER VIDS give us the breathless play-by-pl over an AIR-TO-AIR SHOT of the police hovercopter...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --yes, our Eye In The Sky hovercam's coming through very clearly. You can see the police hovercopter there...and the Hounds below... ...the VIDSCREEN IMAGE ANGLES DOWN, shaky, to the Hounds along the street. Montag steps TIGHT INTO FRAME F.G. , te his gaze from the vids and gazing up toward the sky.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: We're told they've changed direction now. Heading west. Toward the river. Montag's heart sinks. There are hovercopters all over the city. Which one is pursuing him? He forces himself to wai for the light to change, desperate not to attract attenti to himself, sweating bullets all the while.

dialogues.speaker: PUNDIT
dialogues.text: Steve, these Hounds are amazing technology, with a sense of smell a hundred thousand times keener than a real dog's. This gives them instant DNA recognition, which means they can identify a human being simply by smell... The light changes. Montag crosses with the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUNDS
dialogues.text: running, a blur of chrome, a thunder of rubber-padded paw

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: walking faster now, jostling in a flow of pedestrians, he SIRENS, tossing terrified looks behind him...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: All eyes on the monitors: an aerial view sweeping over th streets below. Faces tense.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A CITY BUS is turning the corner, passing by us with its vidscreens blaring --

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ---we'll be patching over any moment now to Police Command, the nerve center of the hunt, live as it happens. I'm told we can even expect a live feed from the police hovercopter itself... -- and it wipes from frame, revealing Montag hurrying tow us. He pauses, looking up, hearing a hovercopter getting closer. Still forcing himself not to run, he steps off th curb, moving out across a wide empty boulevard alone...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ++-as the AERIAL VIEW on the monitor screen shows: A FIGURE crossing a wide empty boulevard below us. Caught the open. Turning and looking up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (on headset) Target acquired. Repeat, target is acquired.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: (listening on earpiece) This just in! Authorities believe they have spotted Montag! still waiting to patch through to that police hovercopter...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag spinning around, panicking, trying to see where hi pursuers are coming from, streetcorner vidscreens blaring

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ---yes, yes, it's confirmed! Monta has been spotted! Where's our live feed?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Everybody riveted to the screens as:

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: I want some nice close shots. I want to see his face.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: I need those overlays now! WHIP PAN TO another console, where a TECH is generating D 3D SCANS of Montag's face -- side view, front view.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A MAN is crossing a wide empty boulevard alone -- not Mon Some homeless guy with a pint bottle in a paper bag. He k turning around, looking up, more and more nervous about t hovercopter up there. Is it following him? Suddenly, the SEARCHLIGHT stabs down, pinning him in a ha of glare. He stands frozen, stunned, shielding his eyes..

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: .-and ONSCREEN we see the homeless guy below us, gazing u taking a few nervous steps back. FLASHING COMPUTER LINES converge on his face, locking in...

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: Switching to overlay now. ---and the man's face is replaced with a perfectly animat DIGITAL OVERLAY of Montag's face...

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Going live?

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: Wait. Put a gun in his hand. The tech enters a fast command. FLASHING LINES converge a putting a digital pistol in the fake Montag's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: Now. Go live. INT - Tv STATION - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: We've got our feed! Going live now to the police hovercopter! WHIP PAN TO A STUDIO MONITOR as the live aerial image pop up, the fake Montag backing away, face clearly visible...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: .-.while the real Montag runs, his terror complete, the c spinning dizzily around him...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: We're live! There he is, there's Montag! That's him! He's running!

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..while the homeless man also runs, panicking now as the hovercopter buzzes him. Suddenly, the Hounds veer into view, streaking toward him He cuts and runs in another direction, sheer panic now, t beasts pursuing him up the street.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He's running! He's got a gun! The Swat APC screeches into view up ahead, cutting him of the troopers in the turrets aiming assault rifles...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -+-as the real Montag slows, heart pounding...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's hemmed in! There's nowhere he can go! -.-and he limps TIGHT TO CAMERA, gazing up. CAMERA COMES AROUND TO REVEAL a vidscreen on the side of building. The live feed. A man with a pistol and Montag's face is running. Screaming. The Hounds are catching up...

dialogues.speaker: NOTHIN'
dialogues.text: ..-and the Hounds leap, taking him down, ripping at him i flurry of titanium teeth, savaging him, dragging the body

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ++-.as everybody watches on the monitors. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: Ah. Happy ending.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: As Montag watches, the image goes to a LIVE HANDHELD SHOT the Swat team running in with rifles poised, surrounding body, the Hounds now backing off...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Montag is down. You can see the troopers converging. We're awaiting word. (pauses, listening) Ladies and gentlemen, Guy Montag is dead. A vicious criminal has been brought to justice. A grave crime against society has been avenged. And you saw it here...live.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: stares at the vid, stunned. He turns away, sickened, look across an empty plaza at: The river. The stone retaining walls are right there. All has to do is walk to it. He starts across the plaza, limping and exhausted. As he nears the river, it's dawning on him that he's free He's done it. He's going to make it out of the city. And then something makes him stop. A sound? An instinct? turns. Slowly. There, across the plaza: Beatty's Hound. Scorched chrome and gleaming teeth. still tracking him. Eyes dilating. Stuttering. Locking in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -+.as Montag stands frozen...the image flashing and stuttering...flashing and stuttering...

dialogues.speaker: THE PLAZA
dialogues.text: Montag cuts and runs, making for the river wall. The Hound launches itself across the pavement to intercep gears grinding but fast as hell. Montag gets to the wall, no time to jump, grabs up a pipe spins to defend himself as the beast leaps -- WHAM! Montag nails the Hound with a terrific blow, sends tumbling. The beast lands on its feet, paws scrabbling fo traction, lunging again. Montag drives it back with a des flurry of blows, hitting it again and again --

dialogues.speaker: LET ME GO
dialogues.text: -- and the Hound snatches the pipe from Montag's grasp, crushing it with his jaws, metal grinding, whipping its h and hurling it clattering away across the ground. Montag tries for the wall. The Hound leaps, hits Montag. both go over, momentum carrying them into freefall... They fall endlessly, Montag holding the beast by the thro keeping its teeth at bay. SPLASH! They hit the river --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and sink into the dark waters, still locked in combat. Hound is inches from Montag's nose, snarling and snapping trying to take his face off... .--but Montag wrenches free. The Hound lashes in utter de fury, for there's one thing Hounds can't do -- float. It sinks away beneath Montag's feet, vanishing into the d brackish depths, jaws still snapping...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -.-and Montag breaks the surface, gasping in great lungfu of air. It's all he can do to keep from drowning as the s current carries him away into the night...

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: leaves the city behind and takes us further and further a the river into the wilderness... . ...with Montag clutching a gnarled old log like a shipwre survivor, too weak to do anything but hold on, the curren carrying him along under the stars... +.-ever toward the mountains, where a faint smudge of ros glow promises a coming dawn...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag and his log are swept gently into a tangle of othe debris, coming to a stop. He's unconscious and shivering, hands like white claws holding the log in a death grip. We're looking at a man at the end of his last frayed rope This would be, literally, his last gasp. Except:

FIGURES ENTER FRAME. Rough-hewn. We won't yet see their f They gather at water's edge, peering down at Montag. Two the men wade into the water, pulling the log closer, pryi him free, handing him up toward the others. Montag is dragged onto the riverbank, though he's not eve aware it's happening. He's out of it, shaking with hypoth and fever...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-and now he's wrapped in skins, being dragged along on rough wooden litter, head whipping with feverish dreams..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-where a nightmare Hound lunges into camera, a blur of and eyes and procaine tongue...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: -.-and Montag CRIES OUT, flailing at phantoms as they dra him further and further into the mountains...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Very quiet here. CAMERA PANS a spill of waning sunlight a the floor, coming to: Montag. He's wrapped in bedding up to his chin. A cool da cloth on his forehead. His eyes flutter open, trying to focus. He's coming back us. As coherency returns, he looks around... -..and sees a LARGE MAN hunkered across the tent, staring him with piercing eyes and a wild tangle of beard. His na is GRANGER. He looks like he's been squatting there for h

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: So. You live. You've been out all day, I was beginning to wonder. Montag tries to speak, but can't manage it just yet. Gran glances to a LITTLE BOY.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Go on, get the others. The boy scampers from the tent. Montag becomes aware of a nonsense elderly woman, MAGGIE, as she leans over and giv him a sip of water.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Thank you. PEOPLE start entering, finding places, hunkering down. Mo finds faces staring at him, not all of them friendly -- W SYKES, MORALES, PEMBERTON, ROYCE. Whispers are exchanged,

dialogues.speaker: MORALES
dialogues.text: Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hypothermia almost did him in. And being in that filthy river all night with all these cuts...I had to pump him full of antibiotics.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: As if we had plenty to spare. We should have left him where he was.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Murdered him, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Just let the river have him. That would have been enough.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Amounts to the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER -
dialogues.text: That's not the way we do things. Not who we are. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: What I don't know is that we can trust him.

dialogues.speaker: PEMBERTON
dialogues.text: That broadcast. The manhunt. Could have been faked. A ploy.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: He could be a plant. They might be looking to crack down on us. Of course they'd have to find us first. What better way?

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: So you do think we should kill him. Granger unsheathes a bowie knife, passes it to Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Go on. You feel most strongly about it. He's all yours.
Sykes holds the knife awkwardly, meets Montag's gaze. Mon glances to Granger, notes his twinkle of amusement as:

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Go on, hell. I'm hungry. Dinner's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Dammit. You know that's not what I mean. We can just leave him behind.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, I say do it. Kill him. Montag looks up as another man enters the tent. Recogniti dawns in Montag's face as CAMERA COMES AROUND to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch owes me money. I bet he didn't bring it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Dillman? Diliman? Dillman comes over, crouches down. Takes Montag's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You're alive.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: More than I can say for you. Caught - your act on the late show. Good reception up here on the handhelds. Wow, some climax. Three Hounds and everything. Great special effects. (leans in) You could'a just left town like I did.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You could've invited me. They share a smile. Beat. Dillman turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: I know this man. He's a good man. Whatever you do to him, you do to me. If he's left behind, I'll be with him. That's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: PEMBERTON
dialogues.text: Your loyalty is admirable. But. (glances to Granger) Is it enough? The question lingers in the air. And then:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He gave me a book once. All eyes go to the tent flap. Clarisse hovers there, peer in, shy but self-determined. Montag is quietly overcome w emotion at the sight of her. She meets his eyes and smile

dialogues.speaker: CLARISSE
dialogues.text: That's Mr. Montag. He used to be a fireman. Looks are traded in heavy silence...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -..and Montag is brought from the tent, Clarisse and Dill at his side. There are tents, pack mules, campfires. PEOP are going about their business, a nomadic tribe of sixty more. Montag draws his share of stares and curious looks. Montag pauses, seeing a man before him. The face is famil it him takes a moment to realize -- it's Clarisse's fathe They stare at each other for a long moment. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I met your uncle. He saved my life. I liked him very much.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Me too. Beat. Clarisse's father offers his hand. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Various groups are eating around the campfires. We find M with Granger and the others:

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: We're breaking camp after dinner. Heading further up into the mountains. Always better to travel at night. Are you up to it?

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'll keep up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Winter's coming on. We'll hook up with a few other groups like ours. We know some abandoned mineshafts, some of 'em go pretty deep. They're not comfortable, but they keep us alive when the snow falls. We'll spend the winter there, hibernating like bears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few groans. 115.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: And catching up on your reading? (off their looks) Faber said you had books. A lot of books. Is that where they are, up in the mines?

dialogues.speaker: ROYCE
dialogues.text: Did he say mines? Or minds? Oh dear, a pun. Montag looks around at their faces, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'm...sorry. I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: We have books. Yes, you could say that. But not the kind you think. We hid them away where nobody could ever find them. Or burn them. (looks around) Go on. Introduce yourselves. Morales leans forward, speaking to Montag:

dialogues.speaker: MORALES
dialogues.text: There was a desert wind blowing that night. It was one of those dry, hot Santa Anas that come down through the mountain passes and curl your hair and make your nerves jump and your skin itch. On nights like that every booze party ends in a fight. Meek little wives feel the edge of the carving knife and study their husbands' necks. Anything can happen. You can even get a full glass of beer at a cocktail lounge. (extends his hand) Raymond Chandler. The Simple Art of Murder. Pleased to meet you. Montag shakes his hand, still confused, as another man sp

dialogues.speaker: ROYCE
dialogues.text: No one would have believed, in the last years of the nineteenth century, that human affairs were being watched keenly and closely by intelligences greater than man's and yet as mortal as his own... And now other voices join in, coming from all around him, words mingling and overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: PEMBERTON
dialogues.text: Listen. Billy Pilgrim has come unstuck in time. Billy has gone to sleep a senile widower and awakened on his wedding day. He has walked through a door in 1955 and come out another one in 1941...

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: ...the man in black fled across the desert, and the gunslinger followed. The desert was the apotheosis of all deserts...

dialogues.speaker: MATHESON
dialogues.text: ...on those cloudy days, Robert Neville was never sure when sunset came, and sometimes they were in the streets before he could get back...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...the seller of lightning rods arrived just ahead of the storm. He came along the street of Green Town, Illinois, in the late cloudy October day, sneaking glances over his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: ...there was me, that is Alex, and my three droogs, that is Pete, Georgie, and Dim, Dim being really dim, and we sat in the Korova Milkbar making up our rassoodocks what to do with the evening... 116. Montag's looking around, nonplussed. He glances to Dillma who starts laughing at the look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: . DILLMAN
dialogues.text: Say hello to the books.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Don't judge us by our covers. (taps his head) Each one of us. A book. With the pages locked away where they can never be burned. (leans over, clasps Montag's hand) I answer to the name I was given, Harold Granger. But I have a secret name. Walter Miller, A Canticle for Liebowitz, published 1959. We have (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: many secret names here. Look around. There's H.G. Wells. Mary Shelley. Jonathan Swift. Lincoln. Shaw. Darwin. Also Matthew, Mark, Luke and John. (beat) Tell me, fireman. What's your secret name going to be?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He had this on him. Still damp, but itll dry... She tosses the paperback of "David Copperfield" to Grange

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Ah. David Copperfield. Dickens. Good one. But thick. You'll have your work cut out for you. Granger tosses the book. Montag catches it. Off his look,

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The tribe comes slowly up the slope of a mountain pass by light of a full moon, ragged knots of people and pack ani Thirty miles behind them is the city, spread out below in ocean of lights.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "Chapter one. I am born. Whether I shall turn out to be the hero of my own life, or whether that station will be held by anybody else, these pages must show..." Montag appears, coming toward us, the paperback in his ha He's got a penlight on it, speaking the words aloud:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: "To begin my life with the beginning of my life, I record that I was born, as I have been informed and believe, on a Friday, at twelve o'clock at night. It was remarked that the clock began to strike, and I began to cry, simultaneously..." His voice trails off. A SOUND has been building, unnotice first, but now loud enough to make him stop and look up. People all along the slope are also pausing, also gazing

A SHRIEKING SOUND is tearing the sky, turning the world h and eerie. Montag sees glowing VAPOR TRAILS forming in the stratosph high above, lit by the moon. Streaking overhead. Toward the city. And then, from a great distance, a WAILING SOUND drifts f the city, rising and falling. CIVIL DEFENSE SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Millie's in bed, watching TV, half dozing. She rises, hea the SIRENS. She's drawn toward the window, wondering what earth that sound is...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Montag sees one of the vapor trails break out of formatio separating from the others and descending now in gentle a toward the city, drifting as silently as thistledown. A PINPOINT OF LIGHT begins to glow brighter and brighter the head of the falling vapor trail, glimmering and halat almost like an angel being born. Montag and the others watch in wonder, still not making s of what they're seeing...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Millie comes to the window, gazing out at the city. A BRI GLOW builds from the sky, descending to earth. She looks her face becoming childlike, enchanted...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: -..and Montag suddenly realizes:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (softly) . Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: (also realizing)

dialogues.speaker: AT THE L--
dialogues.text: Light. Flashing into existence over the city like a silen sun, or the bang at the beginning of creation, stunning a beyond comprehension. The world turns white before us lik million flashbulbs going off at once, turning the people animals on the mountain slope into silhouettes, mules buc men and women falling and throwing themselves to the grou
Granger is caught looking at the detonation, screaming an clapping his hand over his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: THE CITY
dialogues.text: ++-as a wave of holy white fire sweeps through the canyon concrete and steel, shattering buildings like crystal vas taking bridges off their moorings, turning the river to s toppling towers, ripping trains off their tracks, melting glass and beam and rivet to slag...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ..-and Millie never has time to scream as the glare blows through the window and sends her sailing on a wind of whi fire, the walls collapsing and taking flight, a flaming b lamp hurtling through frame...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ..-and Montag pulls his face off the ground as the initia glare subsides enough to see, staring in horror, the ROAR the detonation now rolling across the mountains like a th claps of endless thunder...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Millie.

dialogues.speaker: THE CITY
dialogues.text: +.-and the fire expands ever onward, pushing before it a wave of perfect pristine technology now reduced to flamin debris in the roaring heart of a nuclear furnace, all the great works of humankind now undone...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: +.-and Montag gets to his feet, staring in awe. A HUGE MUSHROOM CLOUD is erupting from the glare, rising the sky. People around him are huddled, sobbing, disoriented. A fe others also get to their feet, watching. The shockwave of wind arrives, turning the mountain slope into a momentary hurricane, trees whipping in a frenzy, knocking some people back off their feet. Montag covers h face with his hands, protecting his eyes. As the wind beg to dissipate, he hears:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Montag! Montag!

Montag looks down the slope. There, far below, stands Dil His arms are spread wide, his face turned toward the mush cloud, his teeth bared in a grimace of what may be either sheer terror or joyous exultation. Let's face it -- in th moment, Dillman's gone just a little bit insane:

dialogues.speaker: DILLMAN
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: HISTORY BEGINS WITH US
dialogues.text: Montag turns, sees people shaking and crying, dazed with Pemberton's running by, wild-eyed and incoherent. Montag him, spins him around. One lens of the man's eyeglasses i cracked down the center.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Which way are the winds blowing?

dialogues.speaker: PEMBERTON
dialogues.text: Wind? What? I...I don't...what?

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: West. Prevailing winds are west. The fallout will blow away from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montag sees Granger on the ground, hands shaking before h sightless eyes. He lets Pemberton go, comes over.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: Granger?

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: I'm blind, fireman. I saw the light. Montag crouches, offers his hand, gentle:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: I'll lead you. Granger takes Montag's hand, squeezes it. His other hand Montag's face, fingers seeking.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Lead? Yes, why not? The fireman will lead.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Lead? Lead where? What are you talking about? Others are gathering. Clarisse appears, helping Montag ge Granger to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: The mines. You said they were deep.

dialogues.speaker: GRANGER
dialogues.text: Pray they are. It's going to be a long winter. Longer than we thought. Montag glances around. A lot of faces are suddenly lookin him, seeking answers or reassurance. Their fear and uncer surround him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: You heard him! Gather your things! Help the injured! Grieve later! We've got a long way to go! Move! They do. People up and down the slope prepare to move on, gathering their things, helping the injured. Montag glances to Clarisse. She's clutching Granger's arn ready to help guide him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG
dialogues.text: turns, taking one last look at his city, a hot wind still rippling his clothes. THE MUSHROOM CLOUD is rising higher and higher, godlike a the fading glare, a roiling pillar of fire bellowing into heavens. DISTANT FLASHES begin appearing here and there on the hor More nuclear explosions, but much too far away to see. AS CAMERA CLOSES IN on Montag, we hear him speaking his m quiet and precious thoughts for the final time...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fire is bright. Fire is clean. Fire sweeps away the clutter of the past...and provides a bright and shining future. ...and as we END ON A FINAL TIGHT CLOSEUP, we see tiny pinpoints of nuclear fire reflected in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: MONTAG'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It is good to burn. This is what I have been taught. This is what I know. (beat) It is all I need to know.
